•• red.
§ 2. After that you may gargle with White-wine, wherein a little Salt of Scurvy-graſs is alſo diſſolved.

div.head: IX. * Gargariſma Synanchicum, A Gargariſm for a Quinſ • e.
div.p: Bate.] ℞ Jews Ears ℥j. white Dog's Turd ʒ vj. Bramble Leaves, M. j. red Roſes, M. ſs. Doves-foot, M. ij. Figs, No viij. Water, q.ſ. boil to lb ij. ſtrain, and add Elder Vinegar ℥j. Honey of Roſes ℥iij. It is good againſt Ulcers of the Mouth, Thruſhes, &c.

Salmon.] § 1. If it be uſed to gargle with, in Quinſies, it is better made with Water, than any thing elſe; but if it be for Thruſhes, Ulcers of the Mouth and Throat, &c. then Red or Clarret Wine is better than Water.
§ 2. In the firſt Caſe it ought to be often uſed; to abate the Inflamation, or diſcuſs the Tumor if poſſible; and as often in the latter Caſe, where cleanſing the Ulcer is required.

div.head: X. * Pedilavium Emmenagogum, A Waſh to provoke the Terms.
div.p:
Bate.] ℞ Mugwort, Penny-royal, Calaminth, Camomile, A. M. iv. Water, q. ſ. boil
to lb viij. With which waſh the Feet.
Salmon.] § 1. If you would have it effectually to perform the Work, there ought to be ſo much, as the Woman may ſit in up to the Waſte, for then it will have a particular Operation upon the Womb.

§ 2. Then after coming out of the Bath, the Matrix it ſelf at leaſt the outward Sheath ought to be anointed with this Mixture. ℞ Oil of Nutmegs by Expreſſion ℥ſs. Oil of Savin. gut. x. Musk gr. iv. mix them.

div.head: XI. * Pedilavium Hypnoticum, A Waſh inducing Sleep.
div.p: Bate.] ℞ White Poppy heads, No xx. white Poppy-ſeed ℥j. Leaves of Lettice, M. iv. Flowers of Water-Lillies, M. vj. Violets, M. jſs. Water, q. ſ. boil them. They provoke Sleep.
Salmon.] § 1. It is a good Medicament as it is here preſcribed; but if you add to it, in the boiling Opium ℥ſs. it will be ſo much the better; and then to bath with it hot.
§ 2. The Opium being added to it, as ſoon as the bath is over, and the Sick in Bed, let the Forehead and Temples be bathed with the ſame.

div.head: XII. * Pedilavium Podagricum, A Waſh for the Gout.
div.p: Bate.] ℞ Roſemary, Hypericon, Penny-royal, Bay-leaves. Mugwort, A. M. iij. Bay-ſalt ℥xij. Sal Armoniack ℥ij. Wheat Bran ℥vj. Water two Gallons, boil, and add Caſtile Soap ℥ij. Spirit of Wine lb ij.

Salmon.] § 1. It gives eaſe in the Gout by waſhing, but it endagers the ſending the Humor up into the Stomach, unleſs before-hand evacuated, or the Stomach is fortified by ſome proper Antidote which may reſiſt it.
§ 2. If Opium ℥j. be diſſolved in the Waſh it will yet be more effectual to the Intention.

§ 3. Immediately after the Waſh is over apply over the place pained this Emplaiſter. ℞ Oil-Olive ℥j. Camphire ℥ſs. grind them together, and add Frankincenſe ℥v. melt, mix, and ſpread it on Cloth or Leather.

div.head: XIII. * Pedilavium Scorbuticum, A Waſh againſt the Scurvy.
div.p: Bate.] ℞ Roſemary, Penny-royal, Bay-leaves, Hypericon, Water-creſſes, A. M. iij. common Salt lb j. Water, q. ſ. boil them, S. A.
Salmon.] § 1. It eaſes Scorbutick pains of the Feet, and takes away Spots of the Scurvy, and other Scorbutick Symptoms attending the Feet, or thoſe parts which are waſht with it.
§ 2. You may waſh with it three or four times a day, but twice a day at leaſt; if Salt of Pot-aſhes ℥iij. be put into it, it will cleanſe more powerful, and better anſwer the Intention.

div.head: CHAP. II. Of OILS.
I. Galbanetum Hartmanni, Hartman's Oil of Galbanum.
div.p: Bate.] ℞ Galbanum, p. j. Spirit or Oil of Turpentine, p. ij. digeſt and diſtil by Retort, S. A.

Salmon.] § 1. You muſt not fill the Retort above a third part full, then put to the Receiver and Lute the Juncture, and diſtil in Sand, or a naked fire, but with degrees of heat, firſt very gentle ſo as to warm the Retort, and by degrees increaſing it to the higheſt, ſo will you have an Acid Spirit, a Volatile white Oil, then a yellow Oil, and at laſt a thick red Oil or Balſam; which you may keep by themſelves as they come over by changing the Receiver.
§ 2. The Acid Spirit and Volatile white Oil, will come over nearly together, and therefore may be taken in one Receiver, and afterwards ſeparated.
§ 3. The other two may be taken ſeverally as you pleaſe, or drawn together, if you intend them only for an outward uſe.

§ 4. The Acid Spirit may be ſeparated from moſt of its Flegm by diſtillation in a Bolt-head; it is Sudorifick and Diuretick, opens Obſtructions
of the Lungs, Reins, and Womb, provokes Urine, and expels malign Humors thro' the Pores of the Skin. Doſe, gut. 30.40. or more.
§ 5. The Volatile Oil is accounted a Specifick againſt Sand, Gravel, and Stone, whether in Reins or Bladder, and prevails againſt the Cholick. Doſe, gut. 10. ad 20.

§ 6. The yellow Oil and Balſam are good againſt Fits of the Mother, Vapors, Wind. Doſe, gut. iij. ad vj. outwardly, they are vulnary, cure Ulcers and Fiſtula's, and eaſe all ſorts of Pains, chiefly thoſe of the Gout.

div.head: II. Galbanetum Sennerti, Sennertus his Oil of Galbanum.
div.p: Bate.] ℞ It is made as the former, adding Chymical Oil of Lavender ℥j. and diſtilling, S. A. It is a wonderful Remedy againſt the Palſie, being anointed upon the part affected.
Salmon.] § 1. The Acid Spirit has the Vertues of the former, and may be given in the ſame Doſe.

§ 2. The Volatile white Oil, has the Vertues of the former alſo, and given in the ſame Doſe; it is a famous thing againſt the Palſie and Convulſions both inwardly taken, and outwardly anointed upon the parts: It gives eaſe in a cold Gout, and in all Pains proceeding from Cold.

§ 3. But if you deſign the whole Diſtillation only for an external uſe, it will be beſt to draw them all off together, and afterward to ſeparate from them the Acid Spirit; ſo will the Volatile Oil, yellow Oil, and red Balſam mix together, which is the Galbanetum of Sennertus.
§ 4. It cures Cramps, Convulſions, Palſies, Lameneſs, Aches and Pains in any part; as alſo green Wounds, old Ulcers, Gouts, &c.

div.head: III. * Oleum Bufonum, Oil of Toads.
div.p: Bate.] ℞ Live Toads, No iv. boil them in Oil-Olive lb ij. for one hour, or till they break; then ſtrain and keep it for uſe. It is good againſt Puſtles of the Lips, and Cancers of the Breaſts; it is alſo prevalent againſt the Dropſie, and provokes Urine, being anointed on the Reins.

Salmon.] § 1. It is ſaid to be an excellent thing againſt all manner of Breakings out of the Skin, of what kind ſoever; and cures a red Face, more eſpecially if mixt with a ſmall quantity of Flowers of Sulphur.

§ 2. I am informed that an old Man who had been troubled with the Gout for forty Years, by anointing the places affected with this Oil for ſome time, was perfectly cured thereof, ſo as he never had any more Fits of it.

div.head: IV. * Oleum Coſmeticum, A beautifying Oil.
div.p: Bate] ℞ Oil of bitter Almonds ℥iv. Oil of Tartar per deliquium ℥ij. Oil of Rhodium, gut. iv. mix them. S. A. It cleanſes the Skin, and ſmooths it.
Salmon.] § 1. It brings off the Skin, but by degrees; it makes not the Face raw, but makes it fall off in manner of a Scurf.
§ 2. If there be Worms in the Face, it kills them all, brings them forth of the Skin, leaving their holes behind, which afterwards fill up again.

§ 3. It ought to be uſed three or four times a day, or oftner, and to be continued for five or ſix Weeks more or leſs, as you ſee occaſion. It will ſmart a little, but without any other detriment, and at length leave the Skin very ſmooth, clear, and white.

div.head: V. * Oleum Cremoris, Oil of Cream.
div.p: Bate.] ℞ The inner green Bark of Elder freſh gathered, M. iij. the beſt Cream lb ij. boil them well, till the Cream turns to an Oil, preſs out, and add more freſh Bark of Elder, M. iv. boil again till the Bark grows criſp, and then expreſs the Oil. It is one of the beſt of Remedies againſt the Piles, Burnings, an Eryſipelas, &c.

Salmon.] § 1. It is good againſt Inflamations of all kinds, as alſo Burnings and Scaldings of all ſorts, by anointing therewith and dipping a Linnen Cloth in the ſame (if need requires) and laying it over the Affect.
§ 2. In uſing it for the Piles or an Eryſipelas; it ought to be often anointed, at leaſt five or ſix times a day; and in the latter you may lay it on with a Feather.

div.head: VI. * Oleum Milvinum, Oil of Kites.
div.p: Bate.] ℞ Young Kites or Gleads from the Neſt, or older with Mag-pyes, No iv. let them be exenterated and deplumed; and boil them in black Cherry-water, q. ſ. adding Peony-roots ℥iij. Caſtor ℥j. Rue, M. iij. Flowers of Roſemary and Lavender, A. M. ij. Flowers of Hypericon ℥j. Roots of Valerian ℥ij. add Oil-Olive lb ij. and boil till they come to a Maſh, or are boiled to pieces; preſs forth, and the Oil which ſwims on top take off, and keep for uſe. At the time of an Epileptick Fit, anoint the Soles of the Feet, Noſtrils, and Nape of the Neck, with this Mixture. ℞ Of the aforeſaid Oil ℥j. Chymical Oils of Rue and Savin, Ana. ℈j. mix them.
Salmon.] § 1. It is chiefly to be done (if uſed preventively) three days before and after the Full and New Moons; otherwiſe I ſhould chuſe to uſe it Morning and Evening the whole Month throughout.
§ 2. During the Unction it will be good alſo to give inwardly. gr. iv. ad x. or xij. (according to Age) of the Volatile Salt of Kites, in ſome proper Vehicle every Morning faſting.

div.head: VII. * Oleum Paralyticum, An Oil againſt the Palſie.
div.p: Bate.] ℞ Muſtard-ſeed lb iij. Caſtor ℥ſs. Cloves ℥ij. Nutmegs ℥iij. S. V. ℥vi. beat all well and digeſt them together in B. M. for twenty four hours, then ſtrongly preſs forth the Oil with a Preſs. Often anoint the Back bone, Nape of the Neck, and parts affected therewith.
Salmon.] § 1. It is a good thing if uſed according to this Compoſition and Preparation, but it will be much more powerful if you add to it a third part of Oil of Amber.
§ 2. You ought to uſe it to all the parts affected, and that Morning and Evening for many days together, giving inwardly Volatile Salt of Vipers.

div.head: VIII. * Oleum Pomoſum, Oil of Thorn Apple Leaves.
div.p:
Bate.] ℞ Freſh Leaves of Strammonium bearing Thorn Apples lb j. bruiſe them and add Oil-Olive lb ijſs. boil to
the Conſumption of the Juice; expreſs, and add freſh Leaves lb ſs. Inſolate for fourteen days, then boil to the Conſumption of the Juice, and preſs out. It quickly heals, even to a Miracle all Inflamations, and all ſorts of Burnings, whether by Fire, or boiling Water, melted Lead, or Gun-pouder, or by Lightning.
Salmon.] § 1. If the Skin be not broken, you need only to anoint it upon the place affected, but often.
§ 2. If the Skin be broken, it will be beſt to apply it Plaiſter-wiſe, and ſo bind it up till the Fire is drawn out; and till that is done, no healing can be expected.

div.head: IX. Oleum Ranarum, Oil of Frogs.
div.p: Bate.] ℞ Live Frogs, No xij. Oil-Olive lb jſs. boil them for an hour, and expreſs the Oil. It cures Redneſs of the Face and Impetigo, helps Eryſipela's and Gangreens, and is a Specifick againſt Cancers.
Salmon.] § 1. It is a good thing for the Intention, but in my Opinion Oil of Toads is much before it, to all the Purpoſes mentioned.
§ 2. It is admirable alſo againſt the Gout, being anointed Morning and Evening, and applied to the part mixt with Barley Meal, as a Pultice.

div.head: X. * Oleum Scorbuticum, The Oil againſt the Scurvy.
div.p: Bate.] ℞ Horſe Raddiſh-roots ℥vj. Scurvy-graſs, M. iv. Lavender-flowers, M. ij. Neats-feet Oil lb j. b •• l with a gentle Fire to the Conſumption of the Juices; pr ••• out and add Spirit of Salt ʒ iij. Spirit of Scurvy-graſs ʒ j. Oil • of Cinnamon and Cloves, A. ʒ ſs. Oil of Origanum ℈iv. mix them. With this Oil the parts affected are anointed once a day, for half an hour very warm.

Salmon.] § 1. But where Scorbutick pains affect in 〈◊〉 cold habit of Body, you muſt (beſides anointing with it) apply it as a Pultice to the parts affected by mixing it with Pouder of Elecampane and Bay-berries, Ana.
§ 2. In a cold Gout it is alſo a Specifick, firſt anointing with it, and then applying it in a Cataplaſm as before directed.

div.head:
XI. Oleum
〈 in non-Latin alphabet 〉
Trichophues, An Oil for reſtoring Hair fallen.
div.p: Bate.] ℞ Freſh Southernwood bruiſed lb ſs. old Oil lb jſs. red Wine lb ſs. boil till the Herbs are criſp; then ſtrain out: repeat this Work the third time with new Southernwood: ſtrain out, and add Bear's-greaſe ℥ij. mix them well. It is mightily commended for the Cure of an Alopecia, or for like falling of the Hair.

Salmon.] § 1. 〈 in non-Latin alphabet 〉
fignificat, quod capillos reſtituit: And Dioſcorides uſes it in that Senſe, where he ſaith, 〈 in non-Latin alphabet 〉 , &c. Lib. 2. Cap. 97.

§ 2. You muſt before you anoint rub the bald places with a warm coarſe Cloth, till they look very red, or you may do it with an Onion in like manner, then anoint with this Oil, rubbing it well in for half an hour at a time, and this repeat three or four times a day, for ſix Weeks together at leaſt.

div.head: XII. * Oleum Tritici, Oil of Wheat.
div.p: Bate.] ℞ It is made by ſtrongly expreſſing bruiſed Wheat, between hot Iron Plates, ſo as the Oil may come forth. It is admirably good againſt Chops in the Hands, Ulcers of the Feet, or Kibes, Chops of the Lips, Herpes, Scabbines of the Skin, &c.

Salmon.] § 1. You may anoint therewith three or four times a day, but chiefly at Night going to Bed, and apply over where it is neceſſary this Emplaiſter. ℞ Emplaſtrum Diapalma ℥j. of this Oil ℥j. Wax ℥ſs. mix them.
§ 2. It is anodyne, abates Inflamations, and is good againſt Scurf, Dandrif, and other Foulneſſes of the Head in Children, being anointed on the part.

div.head: XIII. Oleum Viperarum, Oil of Vipers.
div.p: Bate.] ℞ Large, fat, live Vipers, No 3. Spaniſh Wine ℥ij. Oil of Hypericon ℥viij. put them into a Veſſel with a narrow Mouth, boil in B. M. to the Conſumption of the Humidity, and then preſs forth the Oil. It cleanſes the Skin, heals the Impetigo, &c. takes away Gouty Tophs, cures the Leproſie.
Salmon.] § 1. It is indeed a good thing to cleanſe the Skin, but it muſt be long uſed, except it be fortified with ſome of the Volatile Salt of Toads.

§ 2. And that it might the more effectually anſwer the Intention, while this Oil is uſed outwardly, the Volatile Salt of Vipers ought to be taken daily inwardly, whereby the malign Acid, which is the cauſe of thoſe Diſtempers will be effectually mortifyed.

div.head: CHAP. III. Of BALSAMS.
I. Balſamum Anodynum, A Balſam eaſing Pain.
div.p: Bate.] ℞ CAſtile Soap ℥j. Opium ℥ſs. Camphire ʒ vj. Saffron ʒ j. Alcohol of S. V. ℥xviij. digeſt in Sand, ten days and nights, then ſtrain. Dip Linnen Rags in it, which apply to the pained parts, renewing the Application every fourth hour, till all the Pain ceaſes. It wonderfully allays the Pains of the Gout. Internally it is alſo given, gut. 30.40.50. in Wine.
Salmon.] § 1. It is indeed a famous Balſam for eaſing of Pains, whether inward or outward: outwardly applyed, it ought to be renewed oftner than our Text preſcribes.
§ 2. Inwardly given it not only prevails againſt the Gout, Rheumatiſm, &c. but is of ſingular uſe againſt the Cholick, Gripings of the Guts, and the Stone, whether in the Reins or Bladder.
§ 3. It provokes Sleep, and cauſes reſt, and therefore ought to be given at Night going to Bed.
§ 4. Given, ad ʒ ij. iij. or iv. in a Clyſter it heals the Bloody-flux, and ſtops all other Fluxes of the Bowels.

div.head: II. * Balſamum Faeminarum, The Balſam for Womenkind.
div.p:
Bate.] ℞ Of the ſmall Flowers of the musked Crane's Bill ℥iv. Oil of ſweet Almonds
new drawn lb jſs. inſolate forty days; then expreſs out: add freſh Flowers of Water-lillies and of white Lillies, A. ℥iv. inſolate again twenty days; and expreſs the Oil; to which add Oil of Jaſſemy ℥iv. Civet ʒ j. mix S. A. and make a Balſam. Anoint therewith the Perinaeum, Groins, Loins, Flanks of Women, 〈 in non-Latin alphabet 〉 , in pariendi difficultate, who have hard Labour, or are not eaſily delivered.
Salmon.] § 1. The Oil is much better made by boiling till the Flowers are criſp; and they may all be put in at once, as well as at ſeveral times, by which means it will alſo be ſooner done.

§ 2. But it will be no perfect Balſam without the addition of ſome proper Reſin; of which kind are Turpentines of all ſorts; to the former Oil, after expreſſion you may add, Strasburg Turpentine, Balſam Capivi, Balſam of Tolu, Chio Turpentine, A. ℥jſs. Liquid Styrax ℥iv. which mix well.

§ 3. Being thus compounded, it will be much more powerful for the intended purpoſe, beſides which it will be a very good Vulnerary; and if any of the parts be hurt or torn in the bringing forth of the Child, it will ſpeedily and ſafely heal them.

div.head: III. * Balſamum Lucatelli, Lucatellus his Balſam.
div.p: Bate.] ℞ The beſt Oil-Olive lb iij. Spaniſh Wine lb j. Venice Turpentine waſht in Roſe-water ℥viij. Wax lb j. boil S. A. adding red Sanders in fine Pouder ℥ij. Balſam of Peru ℥j. mix them. Outwardly applied, it is good againſt Burnings, Inflamations, Ulcers, Wounds, &c. Inwardly it is given, ad ʒ j. or ʒ ij. in Wine for inward Bruiſes, Ulcers of the Reins, Stone in the Reins and Bladder, Difficulty of making Water.

Salmon.] § 1. In making of this Balſam ſome few things are obſervable, firſt, That the Turpentine is better unwaſht than waſht, becauſe ſome of its moſt Volatile, Spirituous and Eſſential parts are loſt in that Agitation.
§ 2. Secondly, That Straſburg Turpentine much exceeds the Venice in this Occaſion, as being much more Fragrant and Balſamick; and Cyprus and Chio are yet ſtill better than that.

§ 3. That where ſuch balſamick Reſins are uſed it is not good to boil much the Balſam, after the mixing of them, becauſe much of their Spirituous and Volatile parts flye away in that Action, and therefore it is beſt to boil the Oil and Spaniſh Wine together firſt, to the Conſumption of the Humidity; and then to add the Reſins, mixing them only by a gentle melting together, not boiling.

§ 4. That the Balſam of Peru is too little in quantity ℥ivſs. is as ſmall a proportion as can be put into this quantity, to add any thing of Vertue to the Medicament; and if inſtead of ℥ivſs. you allow ℥ix. the Balſam will be very much the better.
§ 5. In our Pharm. Lond. Lib. 5. Cap. 2. Sect. 50. you may ſee it, according to the Colledges Preſcript, which is in much differing Proportions.
§ 6. The Red Sanders ought to be added after it is off the Fire, and the boiling heat abated, otherwiſe it will not be of any good colour, and then to be ſtirred continually, till it is almoſt cold.

§ 7. When I make it for my own uſe, my Proportions are theſe. ℞ Oil-Olive lb jſs. Spaniſh Wine lb j. boil to the Conſumption of the Wine; then add the beſt Bees wax lb j. when it is melted, put in Strasburgh, Cyprus, or Chio Turpentine lb jſs. Balſam of Peru ℥viij. Red Sanders in fine Pouder ℥ij. melt, mix▪ and ſtir it till it is cold. 'Tis a Balſam without compared.

div.head: IV. Balſamum Momordicae, Balſam of the Balm-Apple.
div.p: Bate.] ℞ It is made of the Fruit thereof, being inſolated for a long time in Oil. It is one of the beſt of things, againſt Wounds and Ulcers; a moſt admirable thing againſt the Haemorrhoides or Piles, Ulcers of the Womb, Ruptures, &c.
Salmon.] § 1. I humbly conceive that by Momordica our Author intends nothing more nor leſs than the Balm-Apple, and in that Sence we have taken him.
§ 2. But moſt Herbaliſts take Momordica to be the Balſamitamas, which is clearly another Plant, and bears no ſuch Fruit as the Balſamina, Viticella, or Balm-Apple-Plant does.

§ 3. This Oil is temperate in reſpect of the firſt qualities, vulnerary, and
cures Pains, chiefly of the Haemorrhoides; it is alſo good for wounded Nerves, Burnings, Ruptures, &c.

div.head: V. Balſamum Nuciſtae, Balſam of Nutmegs.
div.p: Bate] ℞ Nutmegs bruiſed, or beaten lb j. Spaniſh Wine lb ſs. pure new made Butter without any Salt in it lb ij. put them all into a Veſſel which ſtop cloſe, and inſolate for five days; then boil gently to the Conſumption of the Wine, and ſtrain out the Balſam. Its uſe is as well internal as external. It expels the dead Child, and brings forth the Secundine or After-birth, &c. It is exhibited in Wine ad ℥ſs. it eaſes alſo the Pains of the Head and Spleen, &c. outwardly it is anointed upon the part to eaſe all Pains proceeding from Cold, or cold Cauſes.
Salmon.] § 1. This is nothing more or leſs but an Artificial Oil of Nutmegs by expreſſion made by addition of the freſh Butter.

§ 2. The inſolation and boiling being over; whilſt very hot, you muſt preſs out the Oil, but it muſt be with an Almond Preſs as they make Oil of Almonds, or Oil of Nutmegs by expreſſion; otherwiſe a great deal of the Strength and Oil of the Nutmegs will be left behind.
§ 3. It comforts the Head and weakned Viſcera, and is an excellent thing againſt Ulcers of the internal parts; it diſcuſſes Wind, and gives eaſe in the Cholick to a wonder.

div.head: VI. Balſamum Sclopetarium, A Balſam for Gun-ſhot Wounds.
div.p: Bate] rx; Oils of Lineſeed and Turpentine, A. lb j. Verdigriſe ℥ſs. boil them a little, S. A. It is uſed againſt Gun-ſhot Wounds, and old Ulcers, for which purpoſes it has no equal.

Salmon.] § 1. It is an excellent thing againſt Burnings and Scaldings of all kinds, whether with naked Fire, boiling Water or Oil, boiling Pitch or Wax, melt-Lead, or other Metals, Nitre, Gun-pouder, &c.
§ 2. Lay it on with Lint (the part being anointed with it) and then a proper ſticking Plaiſter over it; it will take out the Fire in a very ſhort time, and ſoon after heal the Ulcer.
§ 3. It is eſteemed alſo a moſt excellent thing for the healing all ſorts of putrified Sores, old Ulcers, running Fiſtula's, &c. doing thoſe things which ſacarcely any other outward Medicine will do.

div.head: VII. Balſamum Spinale, A Balſam for the Back.
div.p: Bate.] ℞ Man's Greaſe ℥iv. Gooſe Greaſe, Badgers Greaſe, A. ℥iij. Oil of Bays ℥ij. Sage, Marjoram, Elder, dwarf Elder, Calamint, Origanum, Lavender, A. M. j. boil all to the Conſumption of the Juices, and preſs out; add Balſam of Amber ℥j. Butter of Mace ℥ſs. Petroloeum, Oil of Spike, A. ʒ ij. mix them, S. A. Anoint on the Spina Dorſi, or Back-bone, for the Rickets. Uſe it in the Morning; and at Night a little before going into Bed, lay over it greaſie Wool, as it is new ſhorn off the Sheeps Back, and binding it faſt to with a double Linnen Cloth ſewed on.
Salmon.] § 1. It is deſigned as an external help againſt the Rickets, and it is of good uſe for ſuch Children, as cannot be eaſily made to take things inwardly.
§ 2. But beſides anointing the Back-bone, it will be neceſſary to anoint the Stomach therewith Morning and Evening, as alſo all the Joynts affected.

div.head: VIII. Balſamum Spleneticum, A Balſam for the Spleen.
div.p: Bate.] ℞ Rue, Ground-Ivy, Camonile, Time, A. M.j. beat them together, and add Ox-Gall, Neats-feet Oil, A. lb j. Aqua Vitae ℥j. boil for an hour, and ſtrain out. It is of ſingular Vertue againſt Pains of the Spleen, and all other Pains and Aches proceeding from a cold Cauſe.
Salmon.] § 1. It is a good thing as it is, but if you add to the Compoſition, Camphire ℥ij. it will be much more effectual.
§ 2. While this is uſing outwardly, let the Patient take in the mean time Tinctura Martis every Night inwardly, in ſome proper Splenetick Vehicle.

div.head: IX. * Balſamum Sulphuris Bateanum, Dr. Bate's Balſam of Sulphur.
div.p:
Bate] ℞ Flowers of Sulphur ℥j. Florence Oil-Olive ℥v. boil all with a gentle Fire, (continually ſtirring of it) till it comes to the conſiſtence of a
Balſam. It is moſt efficacious againſt all Ulcers, whether internal or external. Doſe, ad gut. 20. or more.
Salmon.] § 1. It is good againſt Scabs, Itch, Pimples, Redneſs, Scurf, and all ſorts of breakings out of the Skin, taking them away, and making it white, ſoft, and ſmooth.
§ 2. Applied in the Gout, it is of good uſe, and gives eaſe in that Diſeaſe, when many other Remedies fail.

div.head: x.* Balſamum Sulphuris Minerale, Mineral Balſam of Sulphur.
div.p: Bate.] ℞ Linſeed Oil ℥x. Sulphur in fine Pouder ij. boil gently, continually ſtirring it, till it comes to the Conſiſtency of Honey. Let it be applied to the place pained and weakned with the Gout, ſpreading it on Leather or Cloth, and renewing it every third or fourth day.
Salmon.] § 1. This has all the Vertues of the former, and therefore may profitably be uſed to the ſame Intention.

§ 2. In the Gout, &c. anoint with it very well, which done make another part of it into a Cataplaſm, with Pouder of Elecampane-roots and Bay-berries, and apply it after anointing, over the grieved parts.

div.head: XI. Balſamum Sulphuris Rulandi, Rulandus his Balſam of Sulphur.
div.p: Bate.] ℞ Flowers of Sulphur ℥j. Oil of Nuts or Rapeſeed ℥vj. generous Wine ℥ij. digeſt eight days, ſtirring them ſometimes; then boil to the Comſumption of the Wine. It it is a ſingular Eaſer of Pain; A maturative and digeſtive in Wounds of the Nervous parts: Dropt into the Ears, it takes away their Pain.

Salmon.] § 1. It is good alſo againſt all vices of the Skin whatſoever, freeing it from all its Defedations, for which purpoſes it is not lightly to be valued, being only anointed thereon, Morning and Evening for ſome time.
§ 2. It gives eaſe in the Gout, and in all Pains proceeding from Cold and Moiſture; and ſtrengthens weak Nerves; and is a famous thing againſt Wounds in what part of the Body ſoever.

div.head: XII. Balſamum Verum, A True Balſam.
div.p: Bate.] ℞ It is made of Snails with Shells, for a long time and much beaten with an equal quantity of Sugar-Canday, ſo as to become a Balſam. It is good to anoint with in the Small-Pox.
Salmon.] § 1. After the Small-Pox are filled, and come to their full bigneſs, you may ſafely anoint with this Medicine, it drys them and prevents their pitting.

§ 2. You ought to lay it on almoſt as often as it drys, till they become very cruſty; but being applied before they are come fully out, it may endanger their ſtriking in again, which you muſt with all care avoid.

div.head: XIII. † Balſamum Magis compoſitum, Balſam the greater Compoſition.
div.p: Bate.] ℞ Balſam de Tolu, Capivi, Myrrh, Saffrons, Nutmegs, A. ʒ ij. Maſtich, Guajacum, Ammoniacum, Taccamahacca, Caranna, A. ʒ j. Chio turpentine ℥ſs. yellow Wax℥j. Oil of Hypericon ℥vj. Red Roſe-water ℥ ix. melt fi • ſt the Wax with the Oil; then add the Tinctures and exhale the S. V. after add the Roſe-water; which after the cooling, let it be melted again in a gentle heat, and poured forth into another fit Veſſel, to keep for uſe.
Salmon.] § 1. It is one of the beſt Vulneraries (of an Artificial Balſam) in the World, and in the Cure of Wounds does wonders.
§ 2. It alſo cleanſeth running Sores, old Ulcers, and Fiſtula's, and brings them to a ſpeedy Cure.

§ 3. Applied alſo to the Gout, and to weak and pain Limbs, as alſo to a weak Back: It gives ſpeedy eaſe and relief: Inwardly given ʒ j. ad ʒ ij. at Night going to Bed, it is good againſt Stone, Sand, or Gravel in Reins or Bladder.

div.head: XIV. † Balſamum minus Cempoſitum, Balſam the leſſer Compoſition.
div.p: ℞ Chio Turpentine ℥ij. Oil of Hypericon ℥iv, yellow Wax ʒ vj. Red Roſe-water ʒ vj. mix and make the Balſam in the ſame manner as the former.

Salmon.] § 1. It is a ſingular Vulnerary, and cures Wounds almoſt to a Miracle,
yet in my Judgment, it is not ſo good a Balſam as the former.
§ 2. It ſoftens Scrophulous Nodes, Tophs, and Gums and in the Gout, or any Pains of the Nerves, is little inferior to the former.

div.head: CHAP. IV. Of OINTMENTS.
I. Butyrum Amygdalinum, Almond Butter.
div.p: Bate.] ℞ LArge ſweet Almonds (i. e. Jordan Almonds) lb j. macerate them in cold Water and blanch them bruiſe them well in a Marble Mortar, ſprinkling them often (whilſt beating) with a little fair Water. Then add fair Water, q. ſ. till it grows thick like Cream; ſtrain it hard out by preſſing, and put it upon a gentle Fire often ſtirring it, till it begins to boil: then add (that it may coagulate or thicken) Juice of Limons ℥j. ſuſpend it in a good thick Cloth, that there may be a ſeparation of all the ſervſe or thin parts, the Butter remaining behind in the Cloth, which mix with Sugar and Roſe-water, till it is of a pleaſant Taſte. It is a delicate Anodyn; it lenifies or ſoftens, and maturates, and is good againſt the Gripings of the Guts in Children, for which it is very much commended.
Salmon.] § 1. The Sugar with which the Condiment is made ought to be trebble refined; and the Roſe-water ought to be that of Damask Roſes.
§ 2. For external Uſes, it is a good Maturative, and therefore ought to be mixt with Ripners; and mixt with Turpentine, and the Yolk of an Egg, it makes one of the beſt Digeſtives in nature.
§ 3. Inwardly againſt the Griping of the Guts you may give it from ʒ ij. ad ʒ vj. or more, mixing with it, gut. i. ij. or iij. as you ſee convenient of the Oil of ſweet Fennel-ſeeds.

div.head: II. Butyrum Cerae, Butter of Wax.
div.p: Bate.] ℞ It is made of yellow Wax, diſſolved in S. V. and filtrated, ſo that it may remain in the Paper like Butter. Being edulcorated, it may be drank ad ʒ j. as the moſt excellent of Remedies againſt the Dyſentery or Bloody-flux.
Salmon.] § 1. Outwardly it is good to ſtop Fluxes of Humors into Wounds and Ulcers, and to cauſe them ſpeedily to heal.

§ 2. Inwardly it may not only be given againſt a Bloody-flux, but againſt all other Fluxes of the Bowels whatſoever, with good ſucceſs: It ſtops the Flux and ſtrengthens the Parts weakned. Doſe, à ℈ij. ad ʒ ij. twice a day.

div.head: III. * Linimentum Melluminatum, The Honied Liniment.
div.p: Bate.] ℞ Pouder of Columbines, Sage, Mint, Nutmegs, A. ℥ſs. burnt Alum ℥j. Honey ℥iv. mix them. It is good againſt Ulcers of the Gums, Inflamations, Looſeneſs of the Fleſh about the Teeth, &c.
Salmon.] § 1. If there be Ulcers in the Mouth, diſſolve a little of it in Red or Clarret Wine, and gargle therewith: then lay it in ſubſtance with Lint upon the Ulcer it ſelf, till it is cleanſed.
§ 2. It is good for Ulcers in other parts, and induces them to a ſpeedy healing.

div.head: IV. * Linimentum Simplex, The ſimple Linniment.
div.p: Bate.] ℞ Juice of Nightſhade, Oil of Roſes, A. ℥xx. boil to the Conſumption of the Juice, ſtrain, and add Litharge, Ceruſe, A. lb j. mix them, S. A. It is good againſt Cancers in Womens Breaſts, Heats, and Inflamations, Eryſipela's, &c.
Salmon.] § 1. Anoint therewith Morning and Evening, and ſpread it upon ſoft, gentle Leather, and cover the whole Affect therewith.
§ 2. If Saccharum Saturni ℥vj. be added to it, it will be more effectual to anſwer all the Intentions for which it is deſigned.

div.head: V. Mel Saponis, Ointment of Honey and Soap.
div.p:
Bate.] ℞ Common Soap, Honey, A. ℥iv. Salt of Tartar ℥ſs. Fumitory-water ʒ ij. mix
them, S. A. It is a Coſmetick, and ſerves chiefly for whitening the Hands and Face by waſhing therewith. It prevails alſo againſt Burnings, Inflamations, Gout, &c.
Salmon.] § 1. It is one of the beſt of external Remedies againſt the Gout, or any kind of Pain or Tumor of the Joints, being ſpread upon Leather and applied.
§ 2. If you pleaſe you may add to the Compoſition Camphire ℥ſs. it will be more effectual to all the Intentions.

div.head: VI. * Savanetta Coſmetica, A beautifying Soap or Ointment.
div.p: Bate.] ℞ Venice Soap ℥ij. diſſolve it in Juice of Limons ℥ij. add Oil of bitter Almonds, Oil of Tartar per deliquium, A. ℥j. mix, and inſolate ſo long, till it comes to the thickneſs of an Ointment, ſtirring it well every day. Laſtly, add Oil of Rhodium, gut. vj. vel q.ſ. and make an Ointment.
Salmon.] § 1. It clears the Skin and makes it white, ſoft and ſmooth, freeing it from Pimples, Breakings out, Scurf, Morphew, Sun burning, and other Defedations.

§ 2. It is reported, that if it be ſpread thick upon a Cloth, and laid upon the Face, or other parts of the Skin troubled with Lentils, Freckles, and the like, it will take them away; but it ought to lie on two days, and to be renewed two or three times, or till the ſcurf Skin ſeems to come off, which it will do in a little time with the diſcolouring or ſpots upon it, which I have ſometimes ſeen.

div.head: VII. * Ʋnguentum Albuminum, Ointment of the Whites of Eggs.
div.p: Bate.] ℞ It is made by mixing exactly Oil of Roſes ℥ij. with Whites of Eggs ℥iv. S. A. It is one of the beſt of Remedies againſt Burnings, Inflamations, &c.
Salmon.] § 1. Anoint the Inflamation, Eryſipela's, or part burnt or ſcalded with it, then lay over the Affect more of the ſame laid upon Lint, and gently bind it on, renewing it twice a day.
§ 2. It looſens Contractions, and gives eaſe in the Gout, being prudently applied.

div.head: VIII. * Ʋnguentum Antipyreticum, An Ointment againſt Burnings.
div.p: Bate.] ℞ Freſh Gooſedung, Oil-Olive, A.℥iv. Ʋnguentum de Althaea, Oil of Roſes, A. ℥j. Snow-water ℥viij. boil with a gentle Fire, S. A. ſtrain and add Camphire ʒ j. mix them. It is very excellent againſt Burnings, &c.
Salmon.] § 1. Anoint the Burning or Scalding therewith, and then apply it upon a Linnen Cloth, dreſſing it twice a day till the Fire is out.
§ 2. If it be raw, and the Fire be once out by Application of this Ointment, you muſt heal it after the manner of other Ulcers.

div.head: IX. * Ʋnguentum de Aurantiis, Ointment of Oranges.
div.p: Bate.] ℞ Freſh Oranges, but green, and not ripe; No vj. beat them into a Pulp with their Peels; Bay-leaves, M. iv. Sage, Sorel, Marigold, A. M. ij. Juice of Water-creſſes lb ij. freſh Butter lb ij. boil all to the Conſumption of the Juices, then preſs ſtrongly out; to which add freſh Bay-Leaves, and Sage bruiſed as before; Cinnamon ℥j. Nutmegs ℥ſs; boil again, till the Herbs are criſp, and then preſs out again. It is an excellent thing againſt Scabs, Itch, &c.

Salmon.] § 1. What good it will do in the Itch, I know nothing of (the Ʋnguentum de Enula cum Mercurio, or Neapolitanum, are a thouſand times better:) but as to Scurf, Dandrif, Puſtles, Pimples Scabs, and other like Breakings out, it is a ſingular good thing.
§ 2. You may anoint therewith two or three times a day, till the Affect ceaſes.

div.head: X. * Ʋnguentum de Betonica Aquatica, Ointment of Water Betony.
div.p: Bate.] ℞ Water Betony, Sorrel, A. M. vj. bruiſe them, and add freſh new made Butter lb ij. boil till the Herbs are criſp, and preſs out ſtrongly; repeat the boiling with freſh Herbs three times, ſtrain or preſs out again, and add Sulphur Vive in fine Pouder ℥ijſs. Chymical Oil of Orange-peels ʒ j. mix and make an Ointment, S. A. It cures Scabs, Itch, &c.
Salmon.] § 1. Anoint the Scabby or Itchy places with it twice a day, laying over them a Cloth dipt in the ſame, if it can with conveniency be done.
§ 2. It is good againſt Puſtules, and other breakings out of the Face, Scurf and Dandrif in the Head, ſcald Heads, &c. being daily anointed therewith.

div.head: XI. * Ʋnguentum Cephalalgicum, An Ointment for the Head.
div.p: Bate.] ℞ Ointment of Alabaſter, Ointment of Roſes, A.℥ij. Opium ʒ j. Saffron ʒſs. Oil of Nutmegs ʒ j. mix and make an Ointment. It is to be anointed on the Temples and Forehead.
Salmon.] § 1. What and how the Ointments of Alabaſter and Roſes are made, ſee our Pharm. Lond. Lib. 5. Cap. 4. Sect. 26. and 36. where you have their Vertues and Uſes.

§ 2. It eaſes Pain in any part, but chiefly in the Head, for which it is accounted a Specifick: being anointed on the Forehead, Temples, Noſtrils, Pulſes, and Soles of the Feet, it gives eaſe and reſt.

div.head: XII. * Ʋnguentum Crinificum, An Ointment cauſing Hair to grow.
div.p: Bate.] ℞ Labdanum ʒ vj. Bears greaſe ℥ij. Crude Honey ℥ſs. Southernwood in Pouder ʒ iij. Aſhes of Reed-roots ʒ jſs. Oil of Nutmegs ʒ j. Balſam of Peru ʒ iij. mix them.

Salmon.] § 1. It is ſaid to breed Hair, and reſtore bald places, &c. you muſt firſt rub the place a good while with an Onion, till the Skin looks very red, and then you muſt anoint it with this Ointment, laying over it, a Linnen Cloth dipt in the ſame.
§ 2. And that it may be the more effectually done, it ought to be in like manner repeated three or four times a day for five or ſix Weeks together at leaſt.

div.head: XIII. Ʋnguentum Depilatorium, An Ointment taking away Hair.
div.p:
Bate.] ℞ Quick-lime ℥iv. Auripigment ℥jſs. Root of Florentine Orrice ℥j. Nitre, Sulphur, A. ℥ſs. ſtrongeſt Soap-Lees lb ij. mix, and boil to a juſt Conſiſtency: add Oil of Cloves, gut, xx. mix and
make an Ointment, or rather Pultice.
Salmon.] § 1. You muſt uſe it with great caution, becauſe of its corrupting quality, and if it lies too long, it may do miſchief making Marks and Scars upon the place.

§ 2. Spread it thin upon a thick peice of Linnen Cloth, and ſo apply it, or anoint the place therewith, letting it lie for half an hour, more or leſs according to the Nature, Quality, and Thickneſs of the Skin, &c.
§ 3. The Hair being taken off, anoint the place with Oil or Ointment of Roſes. Mynſicht is the Author thereof.

div.head: XIV. * Ʋnguentum Digitalis, Ointment of Fox Gloves.
div.p: Bate.] ℞ May Butter lb iij. freſh Fox Glove beaten, as much as you can well put into it; inſolate for thirty days; then boil S. A. and preſs out ſtrongly. Anoint the places affected with the King's-Evil therewith; for this purpoſe it has no equal.

Salmon.] § 1. You are to anoint therewith Morning and Evening, continually for ſo long time till you find the Affect to ceaſe: It diſſolves Kernels in the Neck, or elſewhere, and takes away all ſorts of Scrophulous Tumors whatſoever.
§ 2. But the Patient ought to purge once a Week with our Pilulae Panchymagogae, and take a Decoction all along of Fox Glove inwardly.

div.head: XV. * Ʋnguentum Faciale, An Ointment for the Face.
div.p: Bate.] ℞ Camphire, Sulphur Vive, A. ʒ ij. Pomatum ℥ij. ſtrong Diaſinapi ſtrained out ℥j. Oil of Rhodium, gut. iv. mix and make an Ointment. It cures a Red Face, Univerſals being premiſed.

Salmon.] § 1. What Preparation of Muſtard-ſeed the Diaſinapi is, is hard to be underſtood, however inſtead thereof you may take common Muſtard, which we uſe for Sawce, ſtraining it thro' a Cloth from the groſs body of the Seed.
§ 2. If you anoint Morning and Evening therewith, for about fourteen days time, it will do wonders, removing not only Redneſs, but Puſtules, Worms, and moſt other Deformities of the Skin.

div.head: XVI. * Ʋnguentum Familiare, The Familiar, or Family Ointment.
div.p: Bate.] ℞ May Butter ℥vij. Wax, Roſin, A. ℥iv. Crude Honey ʒ x. Wheat-flower ʒ vj, mix them, S. A. It warms, moiſtens, looſens, diſcuſſes, cleanſes, ſmooths, ripens and digeſts; and is of familiar uſe for the ſpeedy curing Fellons and Whitloes in Fingers, and Kibes and Chilblains in the Feet and Toes. It alſo wonderfully helps Scorbutick Ulcers in the Feet.
Salmon.] § 1. It is not only good for Fellons, Whitloes, Chilblains and Kibes; but it is of ſingular uſe to abate Inflamations, and bring Puſhes to Ripeneſs and Maturity.
§ 2. Spread it upon Leather, and apply it warm to the part affected, renewing twice a day till you find amendment.

div.head: XVII. * Ʋnguentum ad Fiſſuras, An Ointment againſt Chaps.
div.p: Bate.] ℞ Myrrh, Ginger, Litharge of Silver, A. j. Honey ℥iv. Wax ℥ij. Oil of Roſes ℥vj. mix them, S. A. For the Rich, you may add, Oil of Rhodium, gut. xij. Leaves of Gold, No 10. Otherwiſe thus. ℞ Fine Bole, Myrrh, Ceruſe, A. ʒ ij. Ducks Greaſe, q.ſ. mix and make an Ointment. It cures quickly.

Salmon.] § 1. Any of theſe may do the deed; but this (more common and eaſie) will do the work better. ℞ Beef Suet ℥iij. Wax ℥j. Straſburgh Turpentine ℥ſs. Oil of Bitter Almonds, q.ſ. to bring it into the body of an Ointment being melted together.
§ 2. Anoint here with, Morning and Evening at Bed-time, and in a few days the Chaps will be well.

div.head: XVIII. * Ʋnguentum ad Foveas, An Ointment againſt the Marks of the Small-Pox.
div.p: Bate.] ℞ Oil of ſweet Almonds ℥ij Sperma Ceti ʒ iij. Oil of Rhodium, gut. iv. mix and make an Ointment, S. A. It is a moſt excellent thing to take away the Pittings or Marks of the Small-Pox. It alleviates the Pain, and takes away the Acrimony, &c.

Salmon.] § 1. I would not have you think that this Ointment will take away the Marks of the Small-Pox, when once you have them,
but rather that it is to prevent them.

§ 2. When therefore the Small-Pox are fully come out, to prevent their Pitting, you muſt anoint Morning and Evening with this Medicament; keeping the Face warm, and thereby they will quickly dry up, and come off without any damage.

div.head: XIX. Ʋnguentum Fuſcum, The brown Ointment.
div.p: Bate.] ℞ Colcothar and Flegm of Vitriol, A. ℥j. Celandine Vinegar ℥jſs. Flowers of Verdigriſe ʒ v. clarified Honey ℥iij. mix and make an Ointment, S. A. It is one of the beſt Cleanſers in Wounds and Ulcers.
Salmon.] § 1. This is made in imitation of the Ʋnguentum fuſcum Wurtzij, which you may ſee in our Doron Medicum, Lib. 3. Cap. 4. Sect. 13. and it has the ſame Vertues.

§ 2. And the Directions there for making that, will fully inſtruct you how you ought to make this; and unleſs it be well done, the Medicine will not be of that worth and validity, which you may expect.
§ 3. It is not only a great Cleanſer, but poſſibly the beſt of Remedies againſt all ſorts of running Sores, Ulcers or Fiſtula's, in what part of the Body ſoever.

div.head: XX. * Ʋnguentum Haemorrhoidale, An Ointment againſt the Piles.
div.p: Bate.] ℞ Freſh new made May Butter lb iij. Flowers of Elder and Broom freſh gathered, as many as the Butter will contain being bruiſed: Inſolate for a Month; then ſtir them well about, and bury them in the Earth, that they may putrifie for a Month; afterwards boil, S. A. and preſs the Ointment out. Otherwiſe thus. ℞ Aſhes or Pouder of burnt Cork ʒ j. Camphire ℈ij. Opium gr. vj. Ʋnguentum Populneum ℥jſs. mix them. Anoint upon the place affected.

Salmon.] § 1. Firſt, foment the part very well with hot Claret Wine, which done, immediately anoint the Piles with either of theſe Ointments; which you muſt reiterate, (viz. the anointing) at leaſt five or ſix times a day.

§ 2. But the Fomentation may be made uſe of Morning and Night ſo long as the Ointment is uſed; and the Patient may ſometimes ſit over a Chafing-diſh of Charcole, wherein ſmall peices of Amber are put for a Fume.

div.head: XXI. * Ʋnguentum Herpeticum, An Ointment againſt the Herpes.
div.p: Bate.] ℞ Quick-lime, Auripigment, A. ʒ j. Tartar, Bay Salt, common Soap, A. ʒ ij. Oil of Elder, q. ſ. mix and make an Ointment, S. A. Anoint the place where the Herpes is, very well, and let it lie on twenty four hours: It will produce a Cruſt, which being removed, you muſt anoint with Ʋnguentum Album.
Salmon.] § 1. It is a ſharp Medicine, and muſt be cautiouſly uſed; becauſe of the Poyſon of the Auripigment.
§ 2. I muſt confeſs I am not for ſuch doubtful (if not dangerous) Medicines, but it may be much better uſed to any other part of the Body than to the Face.

div.head: XXII. * Ʋnguentum ad Lumbricos, An Ointment againſt Worms.
div.p: Bate.] ℞ Common Wormwood, Mint, Tanſie, Rue, Leeks, Leaves of the Walnut-Tree, A. M iij. Savin, M. iv. Bears-foot, M. vj. bruiſe them well with Worm-ſeed ℥ij. freſh Bryony-roots ℥iv. Colocynthis, Aloes, A. ℥ij. Bulls Gall lb j. new Butter not ſalted lb v. White-wine lb ij. boil with a gentle Fire to the Conſumption of the Wine and Juices, then preſs forth.
Salmon.] § 1. If Sow-bread ℥j. has been added, it would have been yet better, and more powerful.
§ 2. You may anoint the lower parts of the Stomach, and Belly therewith at Night going to Bed, and in ſome few days you will ſee the Effects; but you muſt be careful that the Child takes not cold.

div.head: XXIII. Ʋnguentum Ophthalmicum, Eye-Salve, or an Ointment for the Eyes.
div.p:
Bate.] ℞ May Butter ℥iv. white Wax ℥j. melt and waſh often with Roſe-water; then (the Water being poured forth) add Lapis Tutia prepared ℥ſs.
Camphire ℈ij. mix and make an Ointment.

Salmon.] § 1. Before you uſe this Ointment waſh the Eyes with our Aqua Regulata, or ſome other proper Eyewater, which done, put ſome of this Ointment into the Eye, and for an hour or there-abouts gently bind it on.

§ 2. You ought to uſe it for at leaſt three or four Months or more, if any Pearl or Film be upon the Eyeſight, and it ought more eſpecially Evening and Morning be put into the Eyes, letting the Patient lie ſtill in the Morning an hour after it.

div.head: XXIV. * Ʋnguentum Paregorgicum, A mollifying or diſcuſſive Ointment.
div.p: Bate.] ℞ Wax ℥vj. Turpentine ℥iv. Honey ℥iij. Wheatflower ℥jſs. Oil of Roſes, Ʋnguentum Haemorrhoidale, A. ℥iv. melt them and make an Ointment, S. A. It is good for Kibes and Chilblains in the Feet.
Salmon.] § 1. It is good againſt Inflamations in any part, chiefly the Piles in Ano, and is uſed with ſucceſs againſt Kibes and Chilblains.
§ 2. The Piles ought to be anointed with it five or ſix times a day, as alſo Morning and Evening: And Kibes ought to be dreſſed therewith twice a day.
§ 3. It diſcuſſes Tumors from cold, which will not brake, and mollifies and ripens ſuch, as Nature has diſpoſed to braking.

div.head: XXV. * Ʋnguentum Piperinum, Ointment of Pepper.
div.p: Bate.] ℞ Pouder of Elecampane, Flowers of Sulphur, A. ℥ij. black Pepper ℥jſs. Ointment of Roſes ℥xvj. Oil of Rhodium ℈ij. mix and make an Ointment. It is a compleat thing for the Cure of Scabs, Itch, &c.

Salmon.] § 1. It is good againſt Puſtules or Pimples in the Face and Skin, Worms, with which many Peoples Foreheads, Noſes, and Chins much abound, and other Deformities of thoſe parts, as Scabs, Breakings out, &c.
§ 2. Anoint with it Morning and Evening for ſome days, laying over (if need ſo requires) ſome of the ſame ſpread upon thick Cloth or Leather.

div.head: XXVI. * Ʋnguentum Soleare, An Ointment for the Feet.
div.p: Bate.] ℞ Garlick beaten to a Maſs ℥iv. Hogs-Lard ℥viij. boil to the Conſumption of the Juice, and preſs out; add Saffron in Pouder ʒ j. Spirit of Salt ℈ij. mix and make an Ointment. Anoint the Soles of Childrens Feet herewith againſt the Cough, &c.
Salmon.] § 1. Applied alſo to the Soles of the Feet in Fevers, it is very profitable to abate the heat of the Fever, and cauſe reſt.
§ 2. And made into a Cataplaſm with Mithridate and Pouder of Myrrh it is a ſingular thing againſt the Gout and all Rhumatick pains.

div.head: XXVII. Ʋnguentum Sympatheticum, The Sympathetick Ointment.
div.p: Bate.] ℞ Oil of Roſes, fine Bole, A. ℥j. Linſeed-Oil ʒ ij. Man's Greaſe, Moſs of a Man's Skull, kill'd by a violent Death, in Pouder, A. ℥ij. Mummy, Man's Blood, A. ℥ſs. mix and make an Ointment, S. A. By this Ointment all Wounds are healed; anointing the Inſtrument by which the Wound was made, once a day, every day, if the Wound be great, otherwiſe, if the Wound be ſmall, once every ſecond or third day may ſuffice. The Weapon is to be kept wrapt up in a clean Linnen Cloth, and in a place not too hot, leſt the Patient ſuffers thereby.
Salmon.] § 1. This is exactly from Barbet; but you may ſee another Compoſition thereof in our Doron Medicum, Lib. 3. Cap. 4. Sect. 7. of which you may take that which likes you beſt.
§ 2. Theſe Ointments are ſaid to perform the Cure, provided the Nerves or Arteries, or ſome principal Member be not hurt. See the place cited, for the more compleat Uſe thereof.

div.head: XXVIII. * Ʋnguentum Virilitatis, An Ointment againſt Impotency.
div.p: Bate.] ℞ Clarified Honey, Oil of Nutmegs by expreſſion, A. ℥ſs. Pyrethrum, black Pepper, Cubebs, A. ℈ ſs. Civet ℈j, Musk ℈ſs. Balſam of Peru ʒ j. mix and make an Ointment, S. A.

Salmon.] § 1. This Medicine wound be better, if it was accuated with Volatile Salt of Vipers, or of Man's Fleſh ʒ j. Balſam of Tolu ʒ ij. and an augmentation of the Civet and Musk each to ℈ij. Chymical Oil of Piſmires ʒ j. mixing them well.
§ 2. The Patient may anoint with it Morning and Night, the whole Penis or Perinaeum, and alſo before the Act, becauſe it ſtimulates mightily.

div.head: XXIX. † Ʋnguentum Haemorrhoidale, An Ointment againſt the Piles.
div.p: ℞ Oil of Roſes ℥jſs. Emplaiſtrum de Minio ℥j. white Wax ℥ſs. being melted add Aethiops Minerale ʒ ij. Opium ℥ſs. Saffron, Nutmegs, Camomile-flowers, A. ʒ j. Syrup of Roſes ℥j. by a gentle heat exhale the Humidity, and mix them well, S. A.
Salmon.] § 1. It is not only good againſt the Piles, which it cures by anointing; but alſo a ſingular and approved thing againſt the Gout, or any vehement Pain in what part of the Body ſoever.
§ 2. Firſt, anoint the part afflicted therewith; then ſpreading it upon Leather, apply it, binding it on.
§ 3. It has been found alſo by Experience to be an excellent thing to diſſolve Tumors, and Kernels in the King's Evil, being applied and renewed every other day.

div.head: CHAP. V. Of CERE-CLOTHS.
I. * Ceratum Album, The White Cerate, or Cerecloth.
div.p: Bate.] ℞ WHite wax ℥iv. Oil of bitter Almonds ℥v. the whiteſt and pureſt Sperma Ceri ℥j. Ceruſe waſhed in Roſe-water ℥jſs. Camphire ℥ſs. mix them, S. A. It ſoftens, reſolves, and is Anodyn: it cicatrizes in the Small-Pox, and fills them. It is indeed an elegant Coſmetick.
Salmon.] § 1. If a little Turpentine or Frankincenſe be mixed with it, it will ſtick the better, and the Cerate will be never the worſe.
§ 2. It may be laid upon Ladies Foreheads and Faces at Night going to Bed, and taken off the next day, to make the Skin fair and ſmooth.

div.head: II. ‡ Ceratum Cephalicum, A head Cerate, or Cerecloth.
div.p: Salmon.] § 1. ℞ Gum Tacamahac, Maſtich, Olibanum, A, ʒ j. Gum Elemi ʒ ij. Wax, Frankincenſe ℥j. Camphire ℈ij. Opium in Pouder ℈j. Oleum Terrae, Oil of Nutmegs by expreſſion, Ana. q. ſ. mix and make a Cerate.

§ 2. Firſt, gently melt the Roſins and Wax; then add the Gum Elemi, after the Pouders, and the other Gums; Laſtly, the Camphire diſſolved in the Oleum Terrae, with the Oil of Nutmegs; malax them together, and make a Cerate, to which if you pleaſe you may add a little Oil of Origanum and Oil of Cloves.
§ 3. I • comforts and ſtrengthens a • old and moiſt Head and Brai • admirably, eaſes the Megrin and Head-Ach, and is of ſingular uſe againſt Colds, Coughs and Catarrhs, &c.

div.head: III. ‡ Ceratum Stomachicum, A Cerate for the Stomach.
div.p: Salmon.] § 1. ℞ Frankincenſe ℥jſs. Gum Elemi, Wax, Ana. ℥ſs. Oleum Petrae ʒ iij. Oil of Cumin-ſeed diſtilled, Oil of Nutmegs by expreſſion, Camphire, Ana. ʒ j. Oil of Ben, q. ſ. melt the Frankincenſe, Gum Elemi and Wax together with a gentle Fire; then being removed from it put in the Oils, in which let the Camphire be diſſolved, adding at laſt the Oil of Ben, ſo much as to give it, its due Conſiſtence.
§ 2. You may ſpread it upon Leather or Cloth, and ſo apply it to the Stomach, renewing it every other day, or as you ſee occaſion.
§ 3. It comforts and ſtrengthens a cold and weak Stomach, cauſes a good Appetite and Digeſtion, removes the Pains thereof, as alſo Pains and Stitches of the Sides, diſcuſſes Wind.

§ 3. Laſtly, being worn for ſome time, it is a Specifick for the
curing of all ſorts of Agues whatſoever, C • olick Pains, Baſtard Pleuri • es, &c.

div.head: IV. ‡ Ceratim Vulnerarium, A Cerate for Wounds.
div.p: Salmon.] § 1. ℞ Wax, Frankincenſe, A. lb ij. Gum Elemi, Chio Turpentine, A. lb j. Balſam de Tolu, de Chili, A. lb ſs. melt the Wax and Frankincenſe at a gentle Fire, then add the Gum Elemi and Turpentine, which being alſo diſſolved. put in laſtly the Balſams de Tolu and de Chili, and continue ſtirring them till it is nearly cold.
§ 2. You may ſpread it upon Cloth or Leather, and apply it to either Wounds or Ulcers, renewing it once or twice a day, as the Nature of the Affect does require.
§ 3. It alſo eaſes Pains in any part being applied proceeding from a cold Cauſe, ſtrengthens weak Limbs and Joints, diſcuſſes Swellings, and gives ſingular eaſe in the Gout and Sciatica.

§ 4. It oftentimes cures green Wounds at one or two dreſſings, and old Ulcers in a very ſhort time; applied over the whole Belly, it gives preſent relief in the Cholick, and in ſhort time after, perfect cure.
V. ‡ Ceratum ad Clavos pedum, A Cerate againſt Corns of the Feet.

Salmon.] § 1. ℞ Gum Ammoniacum diſſolved in Vinegar of Squills and inſpiated ℥ij. Vitriol of Venus ℥ſs. (but ſome uſe Cyprian or Roman Vitriol, which they call the blew Stone, of which they take ʒ jſs.) white precipitate well edulcorated ʒ iij. Strasburgh Turpentine a little, or q. ſ. mix and make a Cere-cloth.
§ 2. You may ſpread it upon Cloth or Leather and apply it, renewing it when it ceaſes to ſtick, or as you ſee occaſion.

§ 3. It is deſigned for the Cure of Corns in the Feet and Toes, for which it is doubtleſs an excellent thing: It prevails alſo againſt old Ulcers, which are hard to be cured, and diſſolves or ſuppurates Veneral Buboes; and is ſaid to be good againſt Gums, Tophs, Nodes, &c. being applied.

div.head: CHAP. VI. EMPLAISTERS.
I. * Diachylon Odoratum, Perfumed Diachylon.
div.p: Bate.] ℞ EMplaſtrum Diachylon ſimplex lb iij. Pouder of Florentine Orrice-roots ℥iij. Oil of Rhodium ʒ ſs. Musk gr. iij. mix and make an Emplaſter, S. A.
Salmon.] § 1. It is anodyn, and reſolves and diſcuſſes Tumors, and alſo of an Emollient Nature, ſoftning and ripening ſuch as will come to Suppuration.
§ 2. The Orrice-root and Oil of Rhodium are added, only to make it ſmell a little the better.
§ 3. It alſo digeſts, gently cleanſes, and conglutinates new Wounds; and is good for a Pain or Swelling in Womens Breaſts.

div.head: II. * Diapalma Odorata, Perfumed Diapalma.
div.p: Bate.] ℞ Emplaſtrum Diapalma (made with Unguentum & Oleum Roſatum, in the place of Hogs-Lard and Oil-Olive) lb iij. melt it, and add Chymical Oil of Rhodium ʒ ij. mix them, S. A.
Salmon.] § 1. It is of a cooling, drying, aſtringent Nature; eaſes Pain, and ſtrengthens weak Parts, and ſtops Defluxions of Humors.
§ 2. It is alſo often ſpread upon Leather and applied to Womens Breaſts to dry up the Milk.

§ 3▪ Applied for a conſtancy to an old running Sore or Ulcer in the Legs, it is poſſibly one of the beſt things in the World, and has ſometimes performed a Cure of that kind, when moſt other things have been uſed and have failed.

div.head: III. * Emplaſtrum Adhaeſivum, A ſticking Emplaſter.
div.p: Bate.] ℞ Diachylon ſimplex, Diapalma, A. lb j. Burgondy Pitch, Sarcocolla, A. ℥iv. vel q. ſ. mix them, S. A. It ſerves for keeping Iſſues open, and freeing them from Inflamation.
Salmon.] § 1. Beſides which, I know it by Experience to be one of the beſt Emplaſters in the World againſt the Gout, in what part of the Body ſoever.
§ 2. It ſticks well, eaſes Pain proceeding from a cold Cauſe, cleanſes and heals Wounds and Ulcers, &c.

div.head: IV. * Emplaſtrum Burgundicum. Of Burgundy Pitch Emplaſter.
div.p: Bate.] ℞ Burgundy Pitch lb j. Pouder of Cloves ℥x. Chymical Oil of Pepper ʒ iij. mix them, S. A. It is of ſingular uſe againſt the Head-Ach, Ophthalmy, Catarrhs, Vapors, &c. being applied to the Shoulders, and Nape of the Neck.
Salmon.] § 1. It ſticks well, and draws ſtrongly, and therefore is a good thing for the Divertion of Humors falling upon any part.
§ 2. It is a Specifick againſt the Gout, being prudently applied, Univerſals being uſed before-hand.
§ 2. It is good againſt Wounds of the Nerves, but ought not to be applied to any depending part.

div.head: V. Emplaſtrum Camphoratum, The Camphorated Emplaſter.
div.p: Bate.] ℞ Camphire ℥jſs. Balſam de Tolu ℥j. Galbanum ſtrained ℥vj. mix them. It is of uſe in the Suffocation of the Womb, Vertigo, &c. being applied to the Navel; and has the Vertues of the Emplaſtrum Diagalbani.
Salmon] § 1. Beſides the Vertues aſcribed to it by our Author; it is a ſingular diſcuſſive, and cures a Gout proceeding from a cold Cauſe.
§ 2. It is a good Vulnerary, and of ſingular uſe in Wounds of the Nerves, Pains, Aches, and Weakneſſes; applied over the Regions of the Stomach and Belly, it prevails againſt the Cholick.

div.head: VI. Emplaſtrum Catarrhalt, An Emplaſter againſt Catarrhs.
div.p: Bate.] ℞ Taccamabacca, Caranna, A. ℥jſs. Emplaſtrum de Betonica ℥iij. Amber in Pouder ℥j. Cloves ℥ſs. Saſſafras Bark, Winter Cinnamon, A. ʒ ij. Balſam de Peru, q. ſ. mix and make a Maſs. It is to be applied to the Head being firſt ſhaved.
Salmon.] § 1. Applied alſo to the Stomach, it comforts it, and diſcuſſes Wind; and over the Region of the Belly, it eaſes the Pains of the Cholick.
§ 2. Applied to the Joints t • ſtrengthens them; and to he Soles of the Feet, it abates the Heat of Fever and cauſes Reſt.

div.head: VII. * Emplaſtrum Diagalbani, Emplaſter of Galbabanum.
div.p: Bate.] ℞ Galbanum prepared with Vinegar ℥xij. Wax ℥viij. Turpentine ℥ v. mix them. S. A. It digeſts, ſoftens, and reſolves Tophs, Nodes, Scrophula's, and other hard Tumors, and eaſes their Pain. It takes away Warts on the Hands and Corns on the Feet; and ſtrengthens the Nerves and Womb.
Salmon.] § 1. I have known it ſucceſsfully applyed to Womens Breaſts, which have been very hard and painful, and much ſwoln; wherein it preſently gave eaſe, and totally diſcuſt the Tumor.
§ 2. Applied upon the upper Region of the Belly, about the Navel, it is ſaid to prevent Abortion, and to cauſe the Woman to go out her whole time.

div.head: VIII. Emplaſtrum Diaſulphuris Rulandi, Rulandus his Diaſulpher Emplaſter.
div.p: Bate.] ℞ Balſam of Sulphur ℥iij. Wax ℥ſs. Colophony ʒ iij. being melted, add the beſt Myrrh in ſine Pouder ℥iijſs. and boil S. A. It infallibly cures all ſorts of Ulcers and Wounds whatſoever.
Salmon.] § 1. It is as good a Vulnerary as a Man ſhall uſually meet with, it cleanſes, conglutinates, drys, and heals to admiration.
§ 2. Spread upon Leather, and applied to the Joints in Arthritick pains, it gives eaſe and removes them: And applied to a weak Back, it comforts and ſtrengthens the part.

div.head: IX. Emplaſtrum Epiſpaſticum, A Bliſtering Emplaſter.
div.p: Bate.] ℞ Burgundy Pitch ℥xviij. Oil-Olive ℥ſs. being melted add Cantharides in Pouder ℥iv. Seeds of Biſhops-weed in Pouder ʒ ij. mix and make a Maſs, that may ſtick firmly.
Salmon.] § 1. You muſt ſpread it upon Leather, and let it lie twelve or fourteen hours more or leſs, according to the nature of the part, and thickneſs of the Skin.
§ 2. Being taken off, apply over the place either Melilot Emplaiſter, or Colewort Leaves, the ſmooth ſide next the Skin, dreſſing it at firſt twice a day.

§ 3. Many times an ill Symptom falls out in applying of this Emplaſter, which is a ſtrange Pain, Heat and Sharpneſs in making of Urine, and ſometimes their Effects are ſuch, as to cauſe piſſing Blood; for all which, I would not have the Patient to be out of Heart, ſince it is nothing but what is uſual.

§ 4. The Remedy of this is, to drink liberally Barley-water (made of that call'd French Barley) caſting away the firſt Water and uſing the ſecond: to this I uſually add an equal, and ſometimes a double quantity of Milk, which I a little ſweeten with trebble refined Sugar: This liberally drank, quickly takes off the Pain.

div.head: X. * Emplaſtrum Febrifugum, An Emplaſter againſt Fevers or Agues.
div.p: Bate.] ℞ Maſtich in Pouder ʒ vj. Aloes ʒ ij. fine Bole ʒ iij. Euphorbium, Saphiſacre, Bay-berries, Fenugreek, Venice-glaſs, A. ʒ ij. Pitch like Soot of Wood, Bay-Salt, A. ʒ jſs. Turpentine ℥iij. vel q. ſ. mix and make a Maſs of Emplaſter, S. A. It oftentimes cures Tertians, and ſometimes Quartans, being applied to the Wriſts three or four hours before the acceſſion of the Fit.
Salmon.] § 1. You may apply it ſo many hours before the coming of the Fit; but you muſt alſo keep it on after it, as long as it will ſtick, and then renew it again.

§ 2. But if you will believe the Tradition, as ſoon as you take it off, you are to caſt it into a River or Brook, which has a Stream, that it may be carried away therewith, and from thence forth, they ſay, the Ague ſhall never return any more.

div.head: XI. Emplaſtrum Haemorrhoidale, An Emplaſter againſt the Piles.
div.p:
Bate.] ℞ Litharge of Silver
lb j. Hogs Greaſe ℥j. vel q. ſ. beat them well together, ſo as to make a Maſs of a fit hardneſs or ſtiffneſs for an Emplaſter; which may alſo be made into Suppoſitories, S. A. as need ſhall require.
Salmon.] § 1. Being applied to the Joints in the Gout, it it eaſes the Pain; and is good to dry up an old Sore, or running Ulcer.
§ 2. Applied to the Back, it ſtrengthens it, and eaſes the Pain thereof, tho' of long ſtanding: In a Suppoſitory it eaſes the Pain of the Haemorrhoides.

div.head: XII. * Emplaſtrum Laterale, An Emplaſter for the Side.
div.p: Bate.] ℞ Flowers of Sulphur ℥v. Roots of Florentine Orrice ℥ij. Cloves ℥ſs. Cumin ℥jſs. being all in Pouder, add Ship Pitch, Burgundy Pitch, A. ℥iv. Turpentine ℥iij. Chymical Oils of Caraways and Rhodium, A. ℈iv. mix them, S. A. It does much good it Pleuritick pains, Phlebonomy being premiſed.
Salmon.] § 1. It is alſo good againſt Puſtles, Botches, Boils, and other breakings out in the Skin, it draws them, and brings them out.
§ 2. Applied to any place where there is Pain, it eaſes it after a ſingular manner, diſcuſſing the Morbifick matter which cauſes it.

div.head: XIII. * Emplaſtrum Mammillare, An Emplaſter for Womens Breaſts.
div.p: Bate.] ℞ Sperma Ceti ℥j. white Wax ℥ij. Galbanum prepared with Vinegar ℥ſs. Oil of Elder, q. ſ. It has no equal in all Scrophulous Tumors, Oedema's, and Hardneſſes of the Breaſts, curdled Milk, &c.
Salmon.] § 1. It is good againſt a Scirrhous, or any hard Tumor in Womens Breaſts, occaſioned thro' a Blow, Cold taken, or Milk curdled therein.

§ 2. Applied to a white Swelling in the Knee, called an Oedema, it diſcuſſes or diſſolves it, eaſes the Pain thereof, if any, and ſtrengthens it: And indeed it is good againſt any hard Tumor in what part of the Body ſoever.

div.head: XIV. * Emplaſtrum Nuchale, An Emplaſter for the Nape of the Neck.
div.p:
Bate.] ℞ Gum Elemi, Turpentine, A. ℥ſs. Olibanum,
Maſtich, Gum Tragacanth, A. ʒ iij. fine Bole ℥jſs. Seeds of Fleawort, Myrtles, Balanſtians, A. ʒ j. Euphorbium ℈j. Burgundy Pitch ℥viij. Caranna ʒ x. Oil of Cloves, Balſam of Peru, A. gut. vj. mix and make a Maſs, S. A. Applyed behind the Ears it takes away the Tooth-ach: Applied to the Nape of the Neck, it helps Ophthalmies, Deſluxions into the Eyes, &c.
Salmon.] § 1. It was invented for the ſtopping of Catarrhs, or Defluxions of Rheum upon any part.
§ 2. Spread it upon Leather, and apply it as long as it will ſtick, then renewing it: It is alſo good againſt Pains and Aches from a cold Cauſe, in what part of the Body ſoever.
§ 3. Applied to the places afflicted with Arthritick pains or the Sciatica; it gives preſent relief, Univerſals being before-hand exhibited.

div.head: XV. Emplaſtrum Opiatum, An Opiate Emplaſter.
div.p: Bate.] ℞ Diachylon magum ℥iv. Quick-ſilver ℥ij. Opium ℥j. mix them. S. A. It wonderfully conduces to the eaſing of Arthritick and Venereal pains.
Salmon.] § 1. Beſides which, it is a moſt excellent thing againſt all Rheumatick pains proceeding from Wind, and Cold, and Sharpneſs of fermenting Humors.
§ 2. Applied to the Reins, it gives eaſe in their Pains, tho' proceeding from the Stone; and ſtrengthens a weak Back.

div.head: XVI. * Emplaſtrum Paralyticum. An Emplaſter againſt the Palſie.
div.p: Bate.] ℞ Pouder of Earthworms ℥iv. Calamus Aromaticus ℥jſs. Galangal ʒ vj. Honey, q. ſ. mix and make an Emplaſter. It has no ſecond in the Palſie, being applied to the parts affected.

Salmon.] § 1. Before the Application of this Emplaſter, you ought to anoint the Paralytick parts, and all along the Back-bone, twice a day with the Oil of Amber before a good Fire, rubbing it well in for above half an hour, for at leaſt three or four days, or longer, according to the continuance of the Diſeaſe.
§ 2. This done, you may apply the Emplaſter over all the parts affected, renewing every other day.

§ 3. And while this is a doing, let the Patient take
every Morning and Evening the following Draught. ℞ Black Cherry-water ℥vj. Powers of Roſemary, Lavender, Limons, Ana. gut. 20. Syrup of Citron-peels ℥jſs. mix them.

div.head: XVII. Emplaſtrum Podagricum, An Emplaſter againſt the Gout.
div.p: Bate.] ℞ Opium, Venice Soap, A. ℥ſs. Emplaſtrum Diachalciteos ℥ ij. mix them, S. A.
Salmon.] § 1. It is a Specifick for the Gout (Univerſals being premiſed) but it will give eaſe in any other pain whatſoever.
§ 2. Before the Application of it, let the places pained be well bathed with the following Mixture. ℞ Tincture of Opium made with S. V. ℥iſs. Camphire in ſmall bits ʒ iij. mix and diſſolve.

div.head: XVIII. Emplaſtrum Saturninum, An Emplaſter of Saturn, or White Lead.
div.p: Bate.] ℞ White Lead ℥iv. white Chalk ℥ſs. Myrrh ʒij. an Amalgama (of Quick-ſilver, p. ij. with Lead, p. j.) ʒ vj. old Lard, q. ſ. to make it into an Emplaſter of a ſtiff conſiſtency in a cold Mortar. It cures callous and malign Ulcers, yea, the moſt rebellious with one only Application, waſhing them firſt (if they be foul) with the Water of the Solution of Lapis Salutis; immediately applying to the Ulcer this Emplaſter, ſpread thick upon Leather; and (if need be) holding it on with a Plaiſter of Diachalciteos put over it, and binding it ſufficiently faſt with a Woollen Rouler; this Application is not to be removed before fifteen days is paſt.
Salmon.] § 1. Beſides the Vertues here aſſigned to it, it is a ſingular thing againſt all Venereal pains whatſoever, whether in the Joints or Shin-bones.
§ 2. It is alſo good againſt Venereal Nodes, Gums and Tophs, and all ſorts of Scrophulous or Strumatick Tumors or Swellings whatſoever, and is eſpecially commended againſt an Oedema in the Knee.
§ 3. You may ſpread it on Leather, and renew it every ſecond day, or third, at fartheſt, bathing with the Mixture in the former Section every time, before you apply the Emplaſter.

div.head: XIX. * Emplaſtrum Scorbuticum, An Emplaſter againſt the Scurvy.
div.p: Bate.] ℞ Flowers of Hypericon: Leaves of Mouſe-Ear, Pauls Betony, Sea Scurvy graſs, A. M. ij. Wormwood, M. j. Oil of Roſes ℥vj. boil till the Herbs are criſp, and preſs out, to which add Deers Suet, Wax, Honey of Roſes, A. ℥ijſs. Wheat Flower ℥ j. mix them, S. A. It is good againſt Scorbutick Ulcers, and Breakings out.
Salmon.] § 1. It eaſes alſo Scorbutick pains in what part of the Body ſoever, being applied.
§ 2. You may ſpread it upon thick Cloth or Leather, and renew it every other day; made up into a Suppoſitory it gives eaſe in the Piles.

div.head: XX. * Emplaſtrum Smecticum, The Cleanſing Emplaſter.
div.p: Bate.] ℞ Red Lead lb jſs. Oil lb ij. white Soap ℥iv, Wax ℥ ij. boil them, S. A. It cleanſes and reſolves, eaſes the Pains of the Back and Joints, diſſipates Contuſions, alleviates the Pains of the Gout, and prevents Abortion, being timely applied to the Back and Navel, and kept continually on.
Salmon.] § 1. It is a Specifick againſt the Gout, and all ſorts of Arthritick pains, ſo that no Plaiſter is more famed for that purpoſe that I know of.
§ 2. Spread it on Cloth or Leather, and apply it, and renew it again, when it will ſtick no longer.

div.head: XXI. * Emplaſtrum Solare, An Emplaſter for the Feet.
div.p: Bate.] ℞ Sheeps Suet ℥iv. Ship Pitch, Roſin, A. ℥viij. Frankincenſe ℥xij. Saffron in Pouder ℥ſs. Cloves, Mace, A. ʒ vj. Cumin-ſeed ℥jſs. Labdanum ʒ vj. mix them, S. A.
Salmon.] § 1. It is applied to the Soles of the Feet againſt Coughs and Colds in Children, and ſuch elder Perſons, who cannot be eaſily prevailed upon to take Phyſick.
§ 2. Applied in violent Burning and malign. Fevers, it is ſaid to draw away the Heat, and give reſt.

div.head: XXII. Emplaſtrum Spaſmaticum, An Emplaſter againſt Cramps and Convulſions.
div.p: Bate.] ℞ Ship Pitch ℥iv. Caſtor, Oil of Coſtus, A. ℥j. mix and make a Maſs: The Title ſhews the Vertues.

Salmon.] § 1. Before you apply this Emplaſter the part or parts affected ought to be Morning and Night, anointed with the Oil of Amber, well chaffed in, and that for three or four days together; which done, this Emplaiſter may be applied.
§ 2. Spread it on Cloth or Leather, and renew it when it begins to leave ſticking.
§ 3. It is an excellent thing againſt all Pains and Aches, Gouts, and Rheumatick Diſtempers proceeding from a cold Cauſe.

div.head: XXIII. * Emplaſtrum ad Strumas, An Emplaſter againſt the King's-Evil.
div.p: Bate.] ℞ Emplaſtrum è Cicuta cum Ammoniaco ℥iv. Gum Elemi ℥ſs. Mercury precipitate ʒ x. mix them. It heals Scrophula's and Struma's, vulgarly the King's Evil.

Salmon.] § 1. It is applied to hard and painful Swellings in Womens Breaſts, (whether occaſioned thro' Blows, or curdled Milk, or a Cold, which the Vulgar call an Ague in the Breaſt) with admirable Succeſs: It eaſes the Pain, ſoftens, and diſcuſſes or diſſolves the Tumor.
§ 2. Spread it on Cloth or Leather, and apply it, renewing it every third or fourth day, and continue the Application till the Tumor or Swelling is wholly vaniſhed.

div.head: XXIV. * Emplaſtrum Synanchicum, An Emplaſter againſt the Quinſey.
div.p: Bate.] ℞ White Dogs Turd in Pouder ℥vj. Crude Honey ℥viij. Wheat-flower ℥ijſs. Wax ℥iv. Oil of Roſes ℥vj. vel q. ſ. mix and make an Emplaiſter. S. A. It is applied to the Jugular, and parts of the Neck below the Ears, where the Pain is.
Salmon.] § 1. It ought to be made large, and to be applied over the whole Throat, from Ear to Ear, and renewed once a day.

§ 2. Mean Seaſon, while this is applying outwardly the Sick ought to take Spirit of Sal Armoniack outwardly,
gut. 20. ad 30. in four or five Ounces of Milk-water, or black Cherry-water.

div.head: XXV. Emplaſtrum Tibiale, An Emplaſter for the Shin-bones.
div.p: Bate.] ℞ Mercury ℥ij. diſſolve it in A. F. ℥ij. add to it Hogs Greaſe ℥iv. boil them in an Earthen Veſſel, continually ſtirring it with an Iron Rod or Spatula, till it comes to the conſiſtency of a ſoft Emplaiſter, by the exhaling of the Humidity; then add yellow Wax ℥j. Pouder of Maſtich and Olibanum, A. ʒ iij. mix and make a Maſs, S. A. It is profitable in the French-Pox, for Nodes, Gums, Tophs, &c.
Salmon.] § 1. It is of uſe for ſuch as have got Nocturnal Pains, and are troubled with Nodes, Gums, &c. on their Shin-bones, to be applied and renewed every fourth day.
§ 2. But while this is a doing, it will be good for the Patient to take inwardly ſome few Doſes of the Prince's Pouder, the Preparation of which, we have taught in the aforegoing part of this Book.

div.head: XXVI. * Emplaſtrum Vermifugum, An Emplaſter to kill Worms.
div.p: Bate.] ℞ Aloes in Pouder ℥j. Colocynthis, Myrrh, A. ʒ iij. Savin, Rue, Wormwood, Tanſie, Wallnut-Tree Leaves, Bryony-root, A. ʒ ij. Wax, Roſin, A. ℥4. Oil of Rue ℥ij. mix and make a Maſs, S. A. Being applied to the Navel, it kills Worms, and brings them forth.
Salmon.] § 1. Spread it upon a round piece of Cloth or Leather, about ſeven or eight Inches in Diameter, and apply it, laying the Center of it over the Navel.

§ 2. But before you apply it, bath the Belly well with this Mixture. ℞ Strong Decoction of Colocynthis ℥iv. with which mix Ox-Gall ℥jſs. and therein diſſolve Aloes in Pouder ʒ ij. adding at laſt Spirit of Wine ℥j.

div.head: XXVII. † Emplaſtrum de Minio Compoſitum, An Emplaſter of Red-Lead Compound.
div.p:
℞ Red Lead half a Pound: Oil-Olive lb j. mix and boil to
blackneſs, continually ſtirring it, adding Colophony lb ſs. It is alſo made with Linſeed-Oil.
Salmon.] § 1. This is the vulgar Gout Plaſter, and an Emplaſter for all ſorts of Aches and Pains in what part of the Body ſoever; and a good one it is; and tho' ſimple, not to be deſpiſed.

§ 2. In making of it, beware you boil it not too much, leſt it be hard and brittle, and ſo, not be apt to ſtick, which it ought to do; and let it be rather of the Body of a Cerate than of an Emplaſter.
§ 3. Spread it on Cloth, and apply it to the parts afflicted, letting it lie on as long as it will ſtick, and then renew it, which repeat as long as there is occaſion or need.

div.head: XXVIII. † Emplaſtrum de Minio Compoſitum aliud: Another Emplaſter of Red Lead compound.
div.p: ℞ Minium or Red Lead ℥iij. Oil-Olive ℥vj. mix, boil, and add Vermilion ℥j. mix them well.
Salmon.] § 1. The Vertues of this are the ſame with the former, and to be made, uſed and applied in the ſame manner; but the Vermillion may be added towards the end of the boiling.
§ 2. It is more powerful than the former to all Intentions, and more diſſolutive, by reaſon of the Vermilion.

p.hi: One Emplaſter added by the Tranſlator.

div.head: XXIX. Emplaſtrum Febrifugum alterum, Another Febrifuge Emplaiſter.
div.p: Salmon.] ℞ Frankincenſe ℥xiv. Oil-Olive ℥ij. vel q. ſ. Vermilion ʒ iij. melt and make Emplaſter than may ſtick.

§ 2. Spread it upon an Oval piece of Leather about eight Inches long and five Inches broad, and apply it to the Pit of the Stomach, letting it lie on as long as it will ſtick; then renew it once more if you ſee occaſion.
§ 2. It cures all ſorts of Agues, whether Quotidian, Tertian or Quartan without any other help, and that moſtly at one Application; In one hundred Examples together, it has not failed of one.

div.head: CHAP. VII. Of CATAPLASMS.
1. * Cataplaſma Apoplecticum, A Pultice againſt the Apoplexy.
div.p: Bate ℞. BRyony Roots freſh, ℥iii. Muſtard ſeed, Black Soap, A ℥ j. Cantharides ʒ vi. beat them well together: add the beſt Vinegar q. ſ. and make a Cataplaſm to be laid upon the Head ſhaved.

Salmon § 1. It is a ſtrong attractive, and draws a Bliſter ſingularly well; it may lye on about twelve or fourteen hours more or leſs; and then being taken off, a Mellilot Emplaſter, or Colewort leaf may be applyed.
§ 2. In theſe kind of applications, the Patient is for the moſt part troubled with a great heat, pain and ſharpneſs in making of Urine, and ſometimes with Piſſing blood: this is uſual.
§ 3. The Remedy is to drink freely and largely Barly Milk, made by mixing Milk with Barley water, and ſweetning it a little with trebble refined Sugar.

div.head: II. Cataplaſma Cephalicum, a Pultice for the Head.
div.p: Bate ℞ Pouders of Cloves, Nutmegs, A. ʒ ii. Guinny Pepper ℥ ſs. Diaſinapi, or Muſtard ʒ vi. ſower Leaven ℥ iii. Spirit of Lavender Compound ℥iſs, vel, q. s. mix and make a Pultice for the Head being ſhaved.

Salmon. § 1. It is a ſtrong attractive, but not to bliſtring; it warms, comfort, and ſtrengthens a cold Head and Brain, and is good to be applyed in Apoplexies, Vertigoes, Lethargies, Megrims, Headachs, &c. from a cold cauſe.
§ 2. Being ſpread upon Leather, let it be applyed over the whole Head, being firſt ſhaved: 'tis a good thing for a Catarrh from a cold and moiſt cauſe.

div.head: III. * Cataplaſma Synanchicum, A Pultice for a Quinſey.
div.p: Bate.] ℞ White Dogs-turd ℥j. Pulp of the Conſerve of Red Roſes ℥ij. Syrup of Meconium, q. ſ. mix and make a Pultice. It is to be applied under the Chin from Ear to Ear, after Blood-letting.
Salmon.] § 1. Lay it very thick upon Cloth or Leather, and lay it over the whole Throat, under the Chin, letting it lie for ſix or ſeven hours, and then renew it.

§ 2. Before application thereof, let the Throat be anointed with Oil of Jews-Ears; which is made by boiling the Jews-Ears (firſt ſteeped in Water for twelve hours) in Oil-Olive till they are criſp, and preſſing out the Oil, and repeating the boiling in like manner with freſh Jews-Ears, to the time.

div.head: IV. Cataplaſma ad Paronychiam, A Pultice againſt Whitlo's and Felons.
div.p: Bate.] ℞ Yolk of one new laid Egg, add to it common Roſin in fine Pouder, q. ſ. Balſam of Peru, gut. vj. vel viij. mix them well together, till they become a Pultice. Apply it to the place affected: It is a famous Medicine.

Salmon.] § 1. I know this by my own Experience, to be an excellent thing againſt Whitlo's or Felons, giving eaſe in the extremity of Pain to admiration: and in a very ſhort time bringing them to ſuppuration, if Nature tends that way.
§ 2. I have done the ſame thing, by mixing Roſin in fine Pouder, with Hogs Lard, as alſo with Beef or Sheeps Suet; tho' this made with the Yolk of an Egg, I think to be the beſt of them all.
* Cataplaſma Peſtilentiale, A Pultice againſt the Plague.

Bate.] ℞ Pidgeons Dung in Pouder ℥iv. Saffron ℥ſs. Mithridate, London Treacle, Muſtard-ſeed, A. ℥j. Turpentine q. ſ. mix and make a Pultice. It is intended for the breaking of Bubo's, After the Bubo is broken, apply this: ℞ Emplaſtrum de Mucilaginibus, Diachylum cum Gummis, & Sticticum, A. ℥iſs. Galbanum ℥ſs. mix them.
Salmon.] § 1. If I might give my Vote, I ſhould be for adding Black Soap ℥iij. Pulp of Onions, raw or roaſted ℥iiſs. Quick-lime ℥j. mixing them.
§ 2. Being applied it ripens and breaks Bubo's in a very ſhort time to admiration, whether Peſtilential or not; and it is a good thing to ripen and break other Tumors alſo.
VI. * Cataplaſma Podagticum, A Pultice againſt the Gout.
Bate.] ℞ Black Soap ℥iv. Yolks of Eggs No ij Saffron ʒ j. Oil of Spike ℥j. mix and make a Pultice, S. A.

Salmon.] § 1. This is a good Medicine as it is, againſt the Gout, and all ſorts of Arthritick Pains; but it would be almoſt ten times more effectual, if to the Compoſition you add. Camphir ℥iſs. ground with the Oil of Spike in a Mortar, and then mixt with Chio Turpentine ℥iv. adding this mixture to the rest of the things.
§ 2. Spread it thick upon Cloth or Leather, and apply it warm renewing it every Twenty four, or Forty eight hours, as you ſee reaſon or need.

div.head: VII. * Cataplaſma Solare, A Pultice for the Feet.
div.p: Bate.] ℞ Freſh Rue ℥ij. freſh gathered Bryony-roots ℥iv. ſ •• r Leaven, Bay-ſalt, Black Soap, A. ℥iſs. Muſtard ℥iij. beat them well together, and add Vinegar, q. ſ. It is to be applied to the Soles of the Feet in Fevers.
Salmon.] § 1. There ought to be added Turpentine ℥ij. ground with the Yolk of an Egg: Camphir, Sal prunellae, A. ℥j.
§ 2. Being applied to the Feet in Fevers, it abates the violent heat, draws down Vapours from the Head, which diſturb the Brain, and cauſes reſt.

div.head: VIII. * Epicarpia Febrifuga, The febrifuge Wriſt-Pultice.
div.p: Bate.] ℞ Pouder of White Hellebor ℥ſs. Nitre ʒ ij. Pulp of Figgs, q. ſ. ſo as to make a Maſs like a Pultice. Apply it to the Wriſts two hours before the Fit of a Tertian.
Salmon. § 1. Spread it upon Leather, and apply it to both Wriſts, letting it lie on all the time of the cold and hot Fit, (if the Ague comes) and when the Fit is over, renew it again.
§ 2. It is reported, that at two applications, or three at the moſt, it has cured Tertians when many other things have failed.

div.head: CHAP. VIII. Of CLYSTERS.
I. * Enema Alexiterium, A Clyſter reſiſting Poyſon.
div.p: Bate.] ℞ SCordium M. j. Citron-ſeeds ʒ iij. Flowers of Elder, of Camomil, red Roſes, of Centory the leſs, A. P. j. Water q. ſ. boil and ſtrain. To ℥x. add Juice of Kermes ℥j. double refined Sugar ℥ſs. mix and diſſolve. It is for the drawing forth Malignity and Poyſon out of the Bowels, &c.
Salmon.] § 1. It is of good uſe after Sweating in the Plague; as alſo after the Meaſles and Small-pox, when they are fully come out, and begin to die again.
§ 2. It is uſed alſo after the taking of Poyſon, when Emeticks will do no good, as alſo after ſtrong and violent Catharticks, which by their force melt the Juices and excoriate, &c.

div.head: II. * Enema Colicum, A Clyſter againſt the Colick.
div.p: Bate.] ℞ Decoctum commune (prepared with Juniper-berries and Fenugreek ſeed A. ʒ iij) ℥x. Infuſion of Crocus Metallorum, Oil of Dil, A. ℥ij. Caſ ••• e Soap, Electuarium Leni ••• um, A. ounce;j. Chimical Oil of Juniper-berries ʒ ſs. mix them, S. A. It is admirable againſt the C •• ick, Iliack Paſſion, Stone, &c.

Salmon.] § 1. O • an external, uſed Clyſter-wiſe, there is ſcarcely a better Medicine in the World, and it may be twice repeated in Twenty four hours, if the Fit goes not off; yea, twice in twelve hours.
§ 2. Outwardly anoint the Stomach, and whole Region of the Abdomen with this: ℞ Oyl of Ben. ʒ j. Chymical Oyls of Rue and Savin, A: ʒ ſs. mix them.

div.head: III. Enema Balſamicum, A Balſamick Clyſter.
div.p:
