Bate.] ℞ A ſtrong Decoction of Horſe-tail ℥vj. Oil of Hypericon ʒ vj. Lucatella's Balſam ℥j. Balſam de Peru ʒ iij. mix them. It is a moſt excellent thing againſt the
Bloody-flux, and to heal the Excoriations of the Bowels, &c.
Salmon.] § 1. This is often given after violent Catharticks, which excoriate the Guts, and many times bring Blood away.
§ 2. I think the Decoction of Horſe-tail will be beſt to be made with Chicken-broth; and adding to each Clyſter S. V. ℥ij. It may be exhibited ſo often, till the Patient becomes well.

div.head: IV. * Enema Dyſentericum, A Clyſter againſt the Bloody-flux.
div.p: Bate.] ℞ A Sheep's-head kill'd with the Wool, and broken to pieces, (the Tongue and Brains being taken out) boil it in Water q. s. ad lb vj, and ſtrain out for Clyſters. You may add Flowers of Camomil, Mallows, and Marſhmallows, &c. Or it may be made of Butter not ſalted ℥x. Sanguis Draconis ʒ ij. red Wine ℥ij. Or otherwiſe, of New Milk ℥xij. Opium ℈j. Saffron ʒ ſs. being boiled, add White Sugar ℥iſs, and the Yolks of two Eggs. They have the ſame Vertues with the former.

Salmon.] § 1. The Medicament according to the Preſcript is good; but if to each Clyſter you add S. V. ℥ij. ad iv. or vj. according as the violence of the Diſtemper, and the occaſion may require, it will be ten times better.
§ 2. And where the Diſtemper has been of long continuance, and the Patient exceeding weak, ſo that Life is diſpaired of, the one half of the Clyſter ought to be Spirit of Wine, or Brandy.

div.head: V. Enema Hyſtericum, A Clyſter againſt Fits of the Mother.
div.p: Bate.] ℞ Decoctum commune ℥x. Camphir ʒ j. Oil of Rue ℥ſs. Honey of Herb Mercury ℥iij. mix and make a Clyſter.
Salmon.] § 1. You ought to put into it Musk gr. x. ground with a few drops of Juice of Limons, whereby its Virtue againſt Hyſterick Fits will be doubled.
§ 2. Anoint the Vulva and Womb with this mixture. ℞ Musk gr. vj. grind it with Adeps Roſarum ℈ſs. which mix with Balſam of Peru ℈j. Oil of Ben ʒ iij.

div.head: VI. Enema Oleoſum, An Oily Clyſter.
div.p:
Bate.] ℞ Linſeed Oil ℥iij. Oils of Camomil and Dill, A.
℥ij. Oils of Scorpions and of Rue, A. ℥i. Oil of Turpentine ʒ ;i. mix them. It is an egregious Medicament againſt the Colick, Stone, &c.

Salmon, § 1. It is a ſingular thing indeed for the named Intentions, and will not fail of anſwering expectation, ſo far as a Clyſter can do: but if inſtead of the Linſeed Oil ℥iij. you ſubſtitute Rape-ſeed Oil ℥iij. it would be much more ſpecifick.
§ 2. Alſo adding to it Spirit of Wine ℥ij. or iij. you will add to the Virtue of the Medicament, and make it more diſcuſſive.

div.head: VII. Enema Terebinthinatum, A Turpentine Clyſter.
div.p: Bate.] ℞ Decoctum Commune ℥xij. Venice Turpentine ℥ſs. Yolk of one Egg: Syrup of Violets ℥iſs. Diaphenicon ℥i. mix and make a Clyſter. It is admirably good againſt the pain of the Stone.

Salmon.] § 1. It is an excellent thing againſt the Colick and Wind in the Bowels: but the chief deſign or intention of it is againſt the Stone and Gravel, whether in the Reins or Bladder, for the eaſing of the pains thereof, it is truly a Specifick.
§ 2. You may repeat it (if you ſee need) twice a day, till you ſee the deſired effects.

div.head: VIII. Enema Vinoſum, A Clyſter of Wine.
div.p: Bate.] ℞ Spaniſh Wine ℥xij. Oil of Aniſeeds ʒ ſs. red Sugar ℥iij. mix and make a Clyſter. It is good againſt the Tormina, or Griping of the Guts.
Salmon] § 1. To make it more abſolute, you ought to add to it Camphir ʒſs. which you may diſſolve in the Oil of Aniſeeds, and ſo mix it with the reſt of the Ingredients.
§ 2. This as well nouriſhes a weak and conſumptive Patient, as gives eaſe to one that is in pain: if the ſick is in a Conſumption, add the Yolk of one or two Eggs to it.

div.head: IX. Enema Ʋrinoſum, A Clyſter of Urine.
div.p: Bate.] ℞ Seeds of Rue, of Daucus, of Cumin, A. ʒ ij. Sena ℥j. Ʋrine lb iſs. boil to one half: ſtrain, and add Species Hiera Simplex ʒ ij. Red Sugar ℥iij. mix and make a Clyſter. It is a good Hydragogue, and prevails againſt the Dropſie.
Salmon.] § 1. It evacuates more Water and Wind than can be well imagined, and does more good than many Catharticks which are given by the mouth.
§ 2. You ought to repeat it once every day, till the hydropick Humor is wholly evacuated, at firſt, for a while, twice a day.
One Clyſter added by the Tranſlator.

div.head: X. Enema Spirituoſum, A Spirituous Clyſter.
div.p: Salmon.] § 1. ℞ Spirit of Wine ℥viij. Oils of Turpentine and Aniſeeds, Ana. gut. 10. Broth of a Sheep's-head ℥viij. mix and exhibit warm.
§ 2. It is a Specifick againſt the Bloody-flux; and therewith I have cured ſeveral which have been at the point of Death.

§ 3. Among the number of the reſt, I cured one poor Man, who had lain twelve Weeks languiſhing under that Diſtemper; I being ſent for, found the Man, as I thought, dead, at leaſt a dying and ſenſleſs, his Eyes cloſed, his Teeth ſet, and ſcarcely any ſigns of Life in him: the miſerable condition of the Man, and importunity of the Byſtanders, moved me to try what I could do for him: I preſently cauſed this Clyſter to be exhibited, he ſeem'd to ſleep and lie quietly after it, reſting twelve hours with it in his Body, and awaked eaſie and pleaſed: it was repeated again, and afterwards once a day for a Week, (diminiſhing ſomewhat of the quantity of the S. V.) and in ſhort time he perſectly recovered, to the wonder of all about him.

div.head: An APPENDIX containing Interjections and Suppoſitories.
XI. * Injectio Alba, An Injection of the White Troches.
div.p: Bate.] Trochiſci albi Rhaſi ʒ iij. Camphir ℈j. Diſſolve them in Frog-ſpawn Water ℥xij. S. A. It allays Inflamations and eaſes Pain, and is effectual againſt Ulcers of the Yard, Gonorrhea's, &c.
Salmon.] § 1. You ought to have a ſhort Syringe, much like an Ear-Syringe, but much leſs, and the Body of it all of a piece with the Spout.

§ 2. Before uſing of it, let the Patient make Water, if he has occaſion, and then exhibit the Injection, injecting three Syringes full at a dreſſing; and after, holding the end of the Syringe in, for about a Minute, before you ſuffer the Water to come forth.

§ 3. This ought to be done at firſt five or ſix times a day, afterwards as the Ulcer begins to heal, three or four times a day, and at laſt but twice a day, till it is well: and it ought to be continued for ſome time after it is ſeemingly perfectly well, leſt it ſhould return again.
§ 4. If it be Winter-time, and cold Weather, the Injection ought to be made Bloodwarm.

div.head: XII. Injectio Auricularis, The Ear-Injection.
div.p: Bate.] ℞ Roſemary-flowers M. ij. boil them in Boys Ʋ rine lb iſs. to lb j. ſtrain out, and add Honey of Roſes ℥iv. mix them. It is good againſt Deafneſs and pain in the Ears.
Salmon.] § 1. It is good againſt Thickneſs of Hearing, Pain and Noiſe in the Ears: It alleviates the Pain in Apoſtems, and brings them to maturation.
§ 2. After the Ear has been well ſyringed with this Injection, you ought to drop into it the following Oil. ℞ Oil of Ben. ℥ſs. Oil of Amber ʒij. mix them.
§ 3. And the Ear is to be ſtopped with Cotton dipt in a ſtrong Tincture of Musk and Ambergriſe, made with S. V.

div.head: XIII. * Injectio Benedicta, An Injection made of the Infuſion of Crocus Metallorum.
div.p: Bate.] ℞ Aqua Benedicta ℥viij. Mercurius dulcis in ſubtil Pouder ʒ iij. mix them well S. A. It has all the Virtues of the Injection made of the White Troches, at Sect. 11. above.
Salmon.] § 1. It is an excellent thing againſt running Sores, old Ulcers, inveterate Fiſtula's, and other like Diſaffections, being uſed two or three times a day.
§ 2. And it prevails againſt a Gonorrhea, being injected four, five, or ſix times a day, as directed at Sect. 11. aforegoing.

§ 3. Exhibited Clyſterwiſe in a Colick. (℥ij. iij. or
iv. to twelve Ounces of Chicken or Mutton-broth) it gives relief to a Miracle, and performs that which no other Clyſter in the World can do beſides.

div.head: XIV. * Suppoſitoria Aluminoſa, Suppoſitories made with Alum.
div.p: Bate.] ℞ Alum in fine Pouder q. v. Whites of Eggs beaten together q. ſ. or ſo much as may make the Pouder of the Alum into a Paſte, of which form Suppoſitories, of ſeveral magnitudes and lengths, which dry for uſe. One of theſe being anointed with Oil, and put up pro re nata, provokes to Stool in ſeveral caſes. They are of ſingular uſe in the Colick.

Salmon.] § 1. The ordinary way which Country People have, is to take a good long piece of Alum, of about a Finger's length, and with a Knife to cut or ſcrape it into the ſhape of a Suppoſitory, and ſo put it up; and this will do full as well.
§ 2. But of the ſhavings or ſcrapings, (that they may not be loſt) you may, if you ſo pleaſe, form Suppoſitories according to this Preſcript.

div.head: XV. * Suppeſitorium Hemorrhoidale, A Suppoſitory for the Piles.
div.p: Bate.] It is made of Chalk and Ʋnguentum Populneum, ſo as to make a ſtiff or hard Maſs, S. A. It cools and ſtops the bleeding of the Hemorrhoids.

Salmon.] § 1. It is of good uſe, where there is a vehement heat, and withal, an untoward Coſtiveneſs of Body, in which caſe it ought to be ſo long uſed, till all the hardened Excrements are come away.
§ 2. It is of a brittle ſubſtance, and therefore muſt be uſed with much tenderneſs, leſt it break in pieces.

div.head: CHAP. IX. Of Medicaments ANOMALOƲS.
I. * Acetarium Scorbuticum, An Antiſcorbutick Sauce.
div.p: Bate.] ℞ SEa Scurvygraſs-(choſen Leaves) ℥iij. Trebble refined Sugar ℥vj. Salt of Scurvy-graſs ℥j. being well bruiſed together, add Juice of Oranges ℥ vj. and mix them. In this you may dip all your Antiſcorbutick Food.
Salmon.] § 1. The Compoſition it good enough as to the Nature of it, but it does not fully anſwer its Name; for the Ounce of Salt of Scurvy-graſs, wholly takes away the pleaſure of it as to a Sauce.

§ 2. In my Opinion, it would be much better to make a Potion of it, by ſtraining all the Syrup out from the Herb, by preſſing, and ſo taking ℥j. of it at a time Morning and Evening in a Glaſs of Antiſcorbutick, or Scurvy-graſs Ale.

§ 3. But leaving out the Salt of Scurvy-graſs it may go then well enough for a Sauce, and that a highly Antiſcorbutick one too; if the Salt muſt be taken, let it be taken in ſome other more proper Mixture, I am ſure it will never make a good Sallet.

div.head: II. Amuleta Peſtilentialia, A Peſtilential Amulet or Preſervative.
div.p: Bate.] ℞ Auripigment ℥jſs. Angelica-roots ʒ vj. Mucilage of Gum Tragacanth, q. ſ. mix and make a Paſte, of which make Amulets, No xij. of a Globe-like form, which roul up in Silk, and hang againſt the Region of the Heart.

Salmon.] § 1. Paracelſus, Crollius, Hartman, and others, are of Opinion, that there is a mighty Power, Force, and Vertue, in ſuch like Amulets, made to defend againſt the Infection of the Plague; I will not ſay much to the Matter, but leave every one to uſe their own freedom.

§ 2. However this I will ſay, that if my own Life lay at ſtake, I ſhould rather truſt to ſome known and approved
inward Specifick Antidote, than to all the fam'd Amulets in the World.
§ 3. Tho' if the Philoſophick Reaſon of the thing be conſider'd and inquired into, there may be much more in it, than many are aware of.

div.head: III. * Caryophylli Odorati, Perfumed Cloves.
div.p:
Bate.] ℞ Styrax Calamita, Labdanum, A. ℥ij. Benjamine ℥j. Cloves ℥ſs.
〈 in non-Latin alphabet 〉 , Charcole ℥iij. make a ſubtil Pouder; add Gum-water, q. ſ. ſo as make a Maſs, of which make little Rouls in the form of Cloves. They are uſed for the fuming of the Bed-Chambers of ſick People.

Salmon.] § 1. Having a fire of live Charcole, you may put ſome few of them upon it, which being ſet in the middle of the Room, will perfume it, in Infectious and Peſtilential times, and among ill ſmelling Diſeaſes.
§ 2. The Fumes alſo received up the Throat by the Mouth thro' a Funnel (whoſe wider part is wide enough to ſpread over the whole Chaſing-diſh) are good to ſtop vehement Coughs, and violent Catarrhs.

div.head: IV. * Caſhew, ſeu Catechu, Rouls of Catechu.
div.p: Bate.] ℞ Catechu in fine Pouder ℥iv. white Sugar-candy ℥ſs. Roch Alum, gr. j. Amber-griſe, gr. iv. Mucilage of Gum Tragacanth made with Roſe-water, q. ſ. mix and make a Paſte, which make into little Rouls, almoſt in the form of Mouſe-turds. They are good to dry up Catarrhs, and conduce admirably to the ſtrengthning of the Head, being held often in the Mouth.
Salmon.] § 1. Being dayly chewed in the Mouth, or otherwiſe held in the Mouth till they diſſolve, they comfort all the Spirits Natural, Vital, and Animal, and cauſe a ſweet Breath.

§ 2. Being eaten every Night going to bed ʒ ſs. ad ʒ j. they ſtop Coughs and Catarrhs, heal Ulcers in the Lungs, and ſtop all ſorts of Fluxes of the Bowels, whether of Blood or Humors, as alſo Fluxes of the Womb, whether White or Red; for which laſt, it is a Specifick.

div.head: V. * Cremor Hordei, Barley Cream.
div.p: Bate.] ℞ Pearled Barley cleanſed ℥iv. boil (caſting away the firſt water) in Fountain-Water, q. ſ. till it is ſoft; beat well the Barley with ſweet Almonds blanched, No 20. then add Barley-water, lb ijſs. mix well, and expreſs ſtrongly, S. A. add thereto trebble refined Sugar ℥ ij. Damask Roſe-water, ℥jſs. ſtir them well and make a Cream. It is diuretick and nutritive, quenches Thirſt in Fevers.

Salmon.] § 1. It is of ſingular uſe to be given upon any Heat, Sharpneſs, or Scalding of the Water, or Piſſing of Blood, occaſioned from the Malignity of Epiſpaſtick Emplaſters, or Bliſtering occaſioned from Cantharides, being often taken ℥ij. iij. or iv. at a time.
§ 2. It is alſo a very good thing in hectick Fevers, abating the Heat, and reſtoring the Conſumptive body.
§ 3. And in other Fevers, it is given to abate their Heat and quench Thirſt, being mixt with Milk-water, or black Cherry-water in a trebble Proportion.

div.head: VI. * Dentifricium Dominarum, A Dentrifice for Ladies.
div.p: Bate.] ℞ Cryſtal prepared ʒ jſs. Pouder of Bricks of Pumice-ſtone, A. ℥ſs. Os Sepiae, Coral red and white, A. ʒ ij. Pearl, Cloves, A. ʒ j. Musk, gr. iv. mix and make a fine Pouder: To which add Honey of Roſes, q. ſ. ſo as to make a ſoft Paſte. Otherwiſe thus. ℞ Pouder of Brick ℥j. Spirit of Sulphur, q. ſ. ſo as to make a Paſte; to which being dryed add, Pouder of Tartar ʒ vj. burnt or toaſted Bread ℥ſs. mix them. Rub the Teeth therewith, and after waſh the Mouth with Wine.
Salmon.] § 1. In the latter Compoſition, Pouder of Cremor Tartari, will be beſt to be choſen, becauſe it is finer, cleaner and more pure than Argol, or unrefined Tartar.
§ 2. If the Teeth be very foul, the Medicament muſt be uſed often in a day, at leaſt five or ſix times; and afterwards, every time after eating.

div.head: VII. * Dentifricium Infantum, A Dentrifice for Children.
div.p: Bate.] ℞ New made freſh Butter ℥j. clarified Honey ʒ vj. red Coral prepared ℥ſs. make a Mixture, S. A. With this let the Gums of Children be rubbed twice or thrice a day, for the more eaſie Breeding of their Teeth.
Salmon.] § 1. But if you would have it do any good, you muſt rub the edges of their Gums with it four, five or ſix times a day.

§ 2. And when all is done, to rub them every hour in the day, with a good Coral is a thouſand times better; for the hardneſs of the Coral falling hard (and that almoſt continually) upon the edge of the Teeth to be cut out of the Gum, does in ſome meaſure deaden (as it were) or benumb the Gum it ſelf, and ſo makes it the more inſenſible of the Pain, and alſo facilitates the cutting of the ſame.
§ 3. And this is the reaſon, that ſuch Children whom their Nurſes are almoſt always rubbing their Gums hard, with a ſmooth Coral, ever breed their Teeth without any pain.

div.head: VIII. * Dentifricium Scorbuticum, A Dentrifice againſt the Scurvy in the Teeth.
div.p: Bate.] ℞ Salt of Scurvy-graſs, Mace, A. ʒ j. Sage ℈iv. burnt Alum ʒ ij. Salt decripitated ℈ij. mix and make a ſubtil Pouder, to which add Honey of Roſes, q. ſ. make a Mixture. You are to rub your Teeth therewith, before the uſe of Dentilavium Scorbuticum in Cap. 1. Sect. 3. of this Book.
Salmon.] § 1. If your Teeth have a Cruſt upon them, and want ſcaling, the Chyrurgeon ought to do it with his Inſtrument, before you uſe this Medicament.
§ 2. This done (if need require) then three times a day, viz. Morning, and after Dinner and Supper, rub your Teeth with this Dentrifice, waſhing them afterwards as directed.

div.head: IX. * Frontale Cephalalgicum, A Cephalick Application to the Forehead.
div.p:
Bate.] ℞ It is made of Roſe-cake, q. ſ. fryed in Vinegar or S. V. and ſprinkled with Pouder of Nutmegs ʒ j. Zedoary ʒ ſs. Camphire ℈ij.
Apply it to the Forehead and Temples.
Salmon.] § 1. It is a ſingular good thing to eaſe the Pain of the Head, and cauſe reſt.
§ 2. In vehement Pains, Vertigo's, Megrims, &c. you muſt often renew it, by moiſtning it with Vinegar, as faſt as you find it dries.

div.head: X. * Lapis Contrayerva, The Stone againſt Poyſon.
div.p: Bate.] ℞ Magiſteries of Harts-horn, of white and red Coral, of Pearl, of white Amber, of Crabs Eyes, A. ʒ ij. Roots of Contrayerva ℥ſs. the black points of Crabs Claws ℥ij, all rightly prepared; mix them together, and with Gelly of Vipers, q. ſ. make it up into little Balls, which cover with Leaf Gold, and carefully dry, S. A. ſome add to the Compoſition Ambergriſe ʒ jſs. It is a famous Cordial, Antidote againſt Poyſon, and Sudorifick, prevails wonderfully againſt the Plague, Small-Pox, Meaſles, and all ſorts of malign Fevers. Doſe, ℈ ſs. ad ʒ ſs.

Salmon.] § 1. Whether you ought to take the Magiſteries of the Corals, Pearl, Amber and Crabs Eyes, or their levigated Pouders only, is not eaſie to be diſcerned by the Preſcript, but either of them will do.

§ 2. There is another Compoſition of this Stone in other Proportions, which you may ſee in our Doron Medicum, Lib. 2. Cap. 24. Sect. 3. which we transferr'd from Monſieur Charras, but in my Judgment, this of our Author is much the more excellent, and may be uſed againſt all malign and peſtilential Diſeaſes from gr. 10. ad ʒ j. in any proper Vehicle. See our Seplaſium, Lib. 7. Cap. 25. Sect. 3.

div.head: XI. Lapis de Goa, The Goaſtone.
div.p:
Bate.] ℞ Of the Hyacinth, Topaz, Saphire, Ruby, Pearls, A. ℥j. Emeralds ℥ſs. Oriental Bezoar, white and red Coral, A. ℥ij. Musk, Ambergriſe, A. ℥ſs. Leaves of Gold, No 40. make all into fine Pouder, which bring into a Paſte with Roſe-water, and form into oblong Balls not much unlike to little Eggs, drying them well in the Shaddow: then with a Limpets Shell, or ſome other thing of like nature, let them be curiouſly polliſhed, that they may have a Gloſs upon them, S. A. It has the ſame Vertues with
the former: Beſides which it is a Specifick againſt Cramps and Contractions of the Nerves. Doſe. à ℈j. ad ʒ ſs. or more.

Salmon.] § 1. 'Tis true you may make it up with ſimple Roſe-water, but then it will be apt to brake with the leaſt fall; your better way will be to add a little Mucilage of Gum Tragacanth, or Gelly of Harts-horn, or ſome ſuch like, which being dryed will make the Stone, not only firmer, but the better alſo to be poliſhed.

§ 2. Some are of Opinion, that you ought to take the Magiſteries of thoſe fragments of precious Stones, &c. but I am confident, that if they be well levigated upon a Porphyry, with a little Roſe-water, it will be full as well; what is required is, that their Pouders be impalpable, and ſoft like Flower.

§ 3. It is an Antidote againſt Plague and Poyſon, and cures the Bitings of Serpents, mad Dogs, or any other venomous Creature; it revives the Spirits, chears the Heart, fortifies Nature, reſiſts Melancholy, reſtores in Conſumptions, prevails againſt all Diſeaſes of the Head and Brain, proceeding from Cold and Moiſture, cauſing a lively Preſence▪ nimble Wit, a pleaſant Countenance, and a ſweet Breath. Doſe, ℈j. ad ʒ j. See its Vertues and Uſe at large in our Seplaſium, Lib. 4. Cap. 65. Sect. 4. ad 8.

div.head: XII. * Linteum Crocatum, Saffron Cloth, or Stay.
div.p: Bate.] It is made by boiling Linnen Cloth with Saffron ʒ ſs. in Rue water, q. ſ. and drying it. It is conſtantly bound under the Chin, during the come forth of the Small-Pox.

Salmon.] § 1. It is an Opinion among the good Women, that a Saffron Stay being applied to the Chin or Throat of the Child in the coming out of the Small-Pox will keep them out of the Throat; but what real efficacy it has upon that account, I cannot tell.

§ 2. This I am ſure of, that a Gargle made of Saffron and Cochinele, A. ʒ ſs. Claret Wine lb j. double refined Sugar ℥ſs. will do feats in that kind, and is much more effectual, that all the external Applications in the World.

div.head: XIII. * Maſticatoria, Spitting Balls.
div.p: Bate.] ℞ Maſtich ʒ iij. Pyrethrum, Staveſacre, A. ʒ ij. Angelica-root ʒ ſs. Cubebs. Nutmegs, A. ʒ j. Euphorbium ℈ſs. Wax q. ſ. mix and make a Maſs, of which make Maſticatories, S. A. That is to ſay, Spitting Balls, or a large ſort of Pills, to be often chewed. They cauſe Spitting, purge the Brain, and help againſt Thickneſs of Hearing, Palſies, and Diſeaſes of the Head proceeding from Cold. They cure alſo the Tooth-ach.

Salmon.] § 1. You are to put one of the Balls into your Mouth, and conſtantly to chew it for ſome time, a quarter of an hour, or half an hour, more or leſs, conſtrantly ſpitting out, as it attracts the Rheum or Spittle.

§ 2. It is good to be uſed in caſe of Defluxions upon any part, eſpecially upon the Eyes, Teeth, Jaws, or Throat: it removes a Catarrh; and by often and long uſing, evacuates the Morbifick cauſe of a Rheumatiſm.
§ 3 It is ſaid to be a ſingular thing to give eaſe in the Tooth-ach, tho' the pain be never ſo extream.

div.head: XIV. * Mixtura Tubularis, A Mixture for the Pipe.
div.p: Bate.] ℞ The outward Hulls of Piſtaches ℥ij. Colts-foots, Betony, Roſemary, all dried, A. ℥iij. let them be cut, and add Raſpings of Lignum Sanctum ℥iij. white Amber, Olibanum, groſly bruiſed, A. ℥iſs. Maſtich ℥j. diſtilled Oil of Nutmegs ʒ j. make a mixture; to be taken as you take Tobacco. Or thus: ℞ Betony, Colts-foot, A. ℥ij. Roſemary Flowers, outward Piſtach ſhells or hulls, A. ℥j. Cardamoms the leſs ℥iſs. cut them, S. A. and add Oyl of Aniſeeds, gut. xvj. Oil of Cinamon gut. viij. mix them. Some add of the best Tobacco cut ℥j. It is chiefly uſeful in drying up Catarrhs, ſtopping of Fluxes of Rheums, Coughs, &c.

Salmon.] § 1. What Virtue there can be in the outward Hulls of Piſtaches for this uſe, I can ſcarcely tell; in my Judgment, if as much dried Sage, or Winter Cinamon prepared, were added in the place thereof, or rather Pimento, the Compoſition would be much better for the Uſes it is intended.

§ 2. It is good to dry up Fluxes of Rheums, ſtop Catarrhs,
caſe the Tooth-ach, help Coughs, expectorate Flegm, and take away the cauſe of a Rheumatiſm, being taken in a Tobacco-pipe, in the ſame manner as you take Tobacco.

div.head: XV. Nodulus Facialis, A Nodulus for the Face.
div.p: Bate.] ℞ Barley parched, q. v. make it into fine Flower, which tie up in a Lawn Rag into a Nodule. With which ſtrew the Face, about the Eleventh Day after the coming out of the Small-pox: it very much defends the Face againſt Scars and Pittings.

Salmon.] § 1. The ſame thing may be done with the Indian Maize, where Engliſh Barley is not to be had, and it yields in parching, both a greater quantity of Flower, and better for the purpoſe, than the other.

§ 2. And for want of either of theſe, you may take unhulled Rice, (in thoſe places where it grows) which will anſwer the ſame end: but if the Rice be hulled, it will not parch well, ſo as to be reduced to a ſoft flowery ſubſtance, but in the parching it will grow dry and hard; the ſame underſtand of Barley.

div.head: XVI. * Nodulus Hyſtericus, A Nodule againſt Fits of the Mother.
div.p: Bate.] ℞ Caſtor in fine Pouder ʒ ſs. Aſſa Fetida ℈j. Oyl of Amber ℈ſs. mix, and tie it up in a bit of Silk in form of a Nodule. Let it be often held to the Noſtrils in time of the Fit.
Salmon.] § 1. If you add to it gut. iv. of Oil of Hartshorn, it will be much the better for this purpoſe.

§ 2. It is good to ſmell to (for ſuch as are troubled with Vapours, or Hyſterick Fits, or ſuch as are apt to theſe Diſtempers, but not uſual with them) at other times, by way of prevention, in which caſes I have known it uſed with ſucceſs.

div.head: XVII. * Panis Diaſarſae, Bread of Sarſaparilla.
div.p: Bate.] ℞ Sarſaparilla ℥iij. China ℥j. Caraways whole ʒ j. fine Wheat-flower ℥xvj. Yolks of Eggs, No ij. a little Yest or Barm; with Milk q. ſ. mix and make a Paſte, of which make Loaves to be baked in an Oven. It may be eaten as ordinary Bread, in the French-Pox, &c.
Salmon.] § 1. It ſweetens the Blood and Juices, and is of good uſe in other Diſeaſes where acid and moiſt Humors abound, as the Scurvy, Dropſie, Gout, Rheumatiſm, Catarrh, &c.
§ 2. If it be baked hard like Biſquit, it will keep longer, eat better, and be more profitable to the ſick.

div.head: XVIII. * Panis de Vipera, Viper Bread.
div.p: Bate.] ℞ Pouder of Vipers Fleſh ℥j. Sarſaparilla ℥iij. finest Wheat-flower lb j. Yolk of one Egg: Yest a little: Milk q. ſ. mix and make a Paſte, of which make four little Loaves, or Cakes, which bake in an Oven, S. A. Let it be uſed as common Bread, in the Cachexy, Scurvy, Leproſie, French-Pox, &c.
Salmon.] § 1. Let this as the former be made into the form of Biſquits, and baked dry and hard like them.
§ 2. Beſides theſe particular Uſes mentioned, it is a moſt ſingular thing to reſtore in Conſumptions.

div.head: XIX. Paſta Halieu • ica, A Paſte or Bait for Fiſhes.
div.p: Bate.] ℞ Henbane-ſeeds ℥ſs. ſtrong old Cheeſe, Cocculus Indi. A. ℥iſs. Wheat-meal two ſpoonfuls, Aqua Vitae four ſpoonfuls Honey q. ſ. mix and make a Paſte, S. A. Break it into very ſmall bits, and caſt it into divers places of the Water, and it will draw the Fiſh.
Salmon.] § 1. You may break it into ſmall bits, about the bigneſs of White Peaſe: but it ought to be caſt in, in a proper Seaſon for Fiſhing, which ſuch as are acquainted with the Art know beſt.
§ 2. And tho' the Fiſh ſeem to be dead, yet they may be eaten ſafe enough, and will eat as well as if taken by other means.

div.head: XX. Paſta Hippiatri, A Paſte or Horſe-Medicine for Farriers.
div.p:
Bate.] ℞ Pouders of Fenugreek, Aniſeed, Cuminſeed, Carthamus Elecampane, Colts-foot, Flowers of Sulphur, A. ℥ij. Juice of Liquorice (diſſolved in White-wine lb ſs.) ℥j. Oil-Olive, Honey, A. ℥viij. Genua Treacle ℥xij. Oil of Aniſeeds ℥j. mix all together, and with Wheat-meal lb iſs. vel q. ſ. make a Paſte, S. A. of which make Balls about the bigneſs of a Man's Fist. Diſſolve one of them in cold Water q. ſ. letting the Horſe drink it all
up at a time; this do Morning and Evening, for fifteen days; in which time it will certainly cure ſuch Horſes as are troubled with Aſthma's, Coughs, and ſeveral other internal Diſeaſes: it makes ſuch fat as are waſted and poor, and makes healthy ſuch as are infirm and diſeaſed.
Salmon.] § 1. This Medicine will do much better in a ſtrong Decoction of Ground Malt, Anglicè-Wort, and given as hot as 'tis convenient for the Beaſt to take it in.
§ 2. And to ſpeak without any thing of a Complement, it is a good thing for what it is intended, and beyond many other Horſe-Medicines, much valued and eſteemed in the World.

div.head: XXI. * Paſta Hypoglottida, A Paſte to take away the Aſperity of the Larynx.
div.p: Bate.] ℞ White Sugarcandy in fine Pounder ℥iv. Oil of Sweet-Almonds new drawn ℥j. vel q. ſ. beat them well into a Paſte. S. A. Hold a little thereof often in the mouth.
Salmon.] § 1. It is of ſingular uſe againſt Coughs, Colds, Shortneſs of Breath, Difficulty of Breathing Wheeſings, Hoarſeneſs, and other Diſtempers of the Latinx, Breſt and Lungs.

§ 2. Let it be held five, ſix, or ſeven times a day, or more, in the Mouth, and ſuffered to diſtil down at leiſure; more eſpecially let it be uſed at ſuch times as the Cough is preſent and troubleſome; but at other times at diſcretion.

div.head: XXII. Paſta Regalis pro Emulſionibus, The Royal Paſte for Emulſions.
div.p: Bate.] ℞ White Poppy-ſeed ℥j. Sweet Almonds blanched ℥iv. Eryngo-root condited ℥ij. The four greater cold Seeds, Ana ℥ſs. Sugar-candy ℥ij. mix and beat them into a Paſte, S. A. At time of uſing it: ℞ Of this Paſte ℥j. Aqua hordeata lb j. mix and make an Emulſion, S. A.
Salmon.] § 1. It is ſingular good againſt pain, heat, and ſharpneſs of Urine, or ſcalding thereof, making of bloody Urine, or piſſing Blood, and the like.
§ 2. The Patient may drink a Draught of the Emulſion about Eight in the Morning: another Draught about Eleven a Clock: a Third at Four in the Afternoon: and the laſt at Night going to Bed.
§ 3. But you ought to be cautious, that the Coldneſs thereof may not hurt the Stomach; if any ſuch thing be perceived, add to the Emulſion ℥j. of Aqua Mirabilis.

div.head: XXIII. * Piſa Lutea, Yellow Peaſe.
div.p: Bate.] ℞ Yellow Oker ℥ſs. Florentine Orrice-root ʒ ij. Wax ℥j. Turpentine, q. ſ. ſo as it may be made up into the form of Peaſe of various Magnitudes. They are uſed to keep open Iſſues.
Salmon.] § 1. That is the principal Intention, and where they are apt to dry up, or will not eaſily be kept open, they are much better than white Peaſe.
§ 2. They draw gently, and abate Inflamations which are ſometimes uſual to thoſe kinds of Sores.

div.head: XXIV. * Piſa rubra, Red Peaſe.
div.p: Bate.] ℞ Vermilion ℥ſs. Hermodacts ʒ ij. Wax ʒ vj. Turpentine, q. ſ. make it up into the form of Peaſe.
Salmon.] § 1. Theſe are ſtronger than the former, and attract Humors more powerfully, by reaſon of the addition of the Hermodacts.
§ 2. But they do it gently, and without any evil Symptoms, by reaſon of the Artificial Cinnabar, or Vermillion, which powerfully corrects all Accidents.

div.head: XXV. * Piſa Viridia, Green Peaſe.
div.p: Bate.] ℞ Verdigriſe, white Hellebore, A. ʒ ij. Cantharides ʒ j. Root of Florentine Orrice ʒ jſs. Wax ʒ vj. Turpentine, q. ſ. Or, you may make them of Verdigriſe, Cantharides, A. ʒ ij. A • ripigmentum ℈ſs. Wax ʒ ij. Turpentine, q. ſ. mix them. They are uſed for Iſſues.
Salmon.] § 1. Theſe are yet ſtronger than the latter, and deſign'd to make their own way, where the Patient will not permit the uſe of the Knife.
§ 2. Afterwards way being made, the Piſa Rubra may be applied till the Iſſue is compleat and runs well; which done, the Piſa Lutea may laſtly be uſed for a conſtancy.

div.head: XXVI. Pomum Ambrae, Pome-Ambers, or Sweet-Balls.
div.p: Bate.] ℞ Styrax Calamita ʒ vj. Benjamine ℥j. Labdanum ʒ ij. white Sanders, Cloves, A. ʒ jſs. Marjoram, Damask Roſe-Leaves, A. ℈iv. Musk, Ambergriſe, A. ℈ſs. Mucilage of Gum Tragacanth (made with Damask Roſe-water) q. ſ. or ſo much as may make up the Ingredients into a Paſte for Balls, S. A. Being held to the Noſe, they ſtir the Blood by their grateful Odor, and chear the Heart above meaſure in Apoplexies, Epilepſies, Peſtilential Airs, &c.

Salmon.] § 1. If they be made into the uſual Magnitude for Pills, they may be taken every Night going to Bed, ad ʒ j. againſt the ſame Diſtempers, and that way uſed they will be more powerful to the Intentions, than by bare ſmelling to them.
§ 2. Beſides which, being firmly made up into little Beads, and bore thro' the middle, they may (when dry) be put in order upon a String, and worn as a Necklace about the Neck.

div.head: XXVII. Pilae Odoratae, Sweet Balls.
div.p: Bate.] ℞ Venice Soap ℥vj. Styrax Calamita, Benjamine, A. ℥ſs. Marjoram ℈iv. Cloves, No 12. Musk, gr. ij. Damask Roſe-water, q. ſ. mix and make Balls, S.A. They cleanſe well, and have a grateful Scent, comforting the Nerves, Skin of the Hands, &c. They ſerve to waſh withal.
Salmon.] § 1. It is good to waſh in the Morning with them, for cleanſing, and whitening the Skin, the conſtant uſe of which will make it very pure and ſoft.
§ 2. It is good to waſh the Head alſo with them in a warm Larder, which is troubled with Scurf, Dandrif, or other Defedations uſual to thoſe parts.

div.head: XXVIII. Suffimentum Hyſtericum, An Hyſterick Fume.
div.p: Bate.] ℞ Aſa fetida ℥j. Rue, M. j. beſt Wine-Vinegar lb j. boil them in a Pot with a narrow Mouth, S. A. The hot Fumes are to be received often in a day up the Mouth (being open) and Noſtrils.
Salmon.] § 1. If at the ſame time the Patient takes fifty or ſixty Drops of the Liquor inwardly in any proper Hyſterick water, it will be much more effectual.
§ 2. But uſing it as a Fume, there ought to be added to it Oil of Harts-horn ℥ſs. whereby the Power of it for this purpoſe will be ten times increaſed.

div.head: XXIX. * Torquis Infantum, A Necklace for Children.
div.p: Bate.] It is made of the male Peony-root and Henbane-root freſh gathered, cut into round pieces and bored thro' the middle, and ſtrung in order upon a Thread or String. Which being wrapped in fine Linnen or Lawn, are to be worn about the Neck in the time of breeding of Teeth. They are ſaid to facilitate the breeding of Teeth, and prevent Convulſions.
Salmon.] § 1. It is uſed as an Amulet, in which I believe there is no more Vertue for driving away Pains in breeding of Teeth, than there is in the Words being worn about the Neck as a Pentacle.

§ 2. But for ſuch as have Faith in the thing (and I know not but their Faith may do the Work) they may put it about their Childrens Necks, and let them wear it as long as they are breeding their Teeth.

§ 3. If in this time, the Child ſhould be croſs and froward, and peeviſh, with the anguiſh of its Teeth cutting, the Parent or Putter on thereof muſt wholly blame themſelves (and not the Medicine) for that they were People of little Faith.

div.head: XXX. * Turundae Acouſticae, Ear Tents to help the Hearing.
div.p: Bate.] ℞ Galbanum, Ship Pitch, A. ʒ ij. white Hellebore in fine Pouder ℈ 5. Civet, gr. vj. mix them; divide the Maſs into eight or ten parts, making each into the form of a Clove; which wrap or tie up in a very thin piece of fine Linnen or Lawn, fixing a Thread to the greater end thereof, for the more eaſie pulling it forth again out of the Ear. It is one of the beſt of Remedies againſt Deafneſs.
Salmon.] § 1. It may be a good thing for all that I know, but I have had no Experience of it, and therefore only recommend it to your Prudence in making Tryal.

§ 2. I muſt confeſs, I admire not the white Hellebore in it (becauſe it is of a putrefactive Quality) and within ℈j. it is nearly half as much as the reſt of the Ingredients; but poſſibly the Emplaſtick Bodies of the Gum and Roſin, may ſo chain or fetter it up, as that it may do no great miſchief.

div.head: An APPENDIX to the former Book.
CHAP. X. TABƲLA POSOLOGICA.
div.p: THis is fitted for the more eaſie computing the Doſes or Quantities of certain Ingredients, going into ſeveral of the Compoſitions in the laſt Edition of the London Diſpenſatory: In ſome of them the Doſes of the purging Ingredients are computed exactly; in others, as near as the Proportion to the given Quantities would hear.

div.head: CHAP. XI. Orthotonia Verborum Medicinalium.

p.hi: THis laſt Chapter ſhewing the true Pronountiation of certain Medical Words, is added for the ſakes of ſuch Apothecaries and others, who, by reaſon of Ignorance, or from meer uſe, are wont to pronounce them falſe, without regard to their true Quantities, which are here noted, to avoid that Error.

div.head: Two General RULES.
div.p: I. ADjectives in [inus] derived from Senſitive Animals, from the Names of Families, alſo from proper Names, and Names of Countries are long in the Penultima, or the laſt Syllable ſave one. As,

II. Adjectives in [inus] derived from things non-animate, viz. from Herbs or Plants, Stones, and various other Matters (of which kind are many formed of Greek Words:) Alſo Adjectives derived from Adverbs of Time, or from Subſtantives denoting the four Principal Seaſons of the Year, are always ſhort in the Penultima, or laſt Syllable ſave one. As,

div.head: ADVERTISEMENT.
div.p: AT the ſign of the Archimedes and Spectacles, in Ludgate-ſtreet, near the Weſt-End of St. Pauls, lives John Marſhall, who both Turns and Grinds, makes and ſells all ſorts of Glaſs Inſtruments, as Perſpective Glaſſes, Teleſcopes, Microſcopes ſingle and double, Horoſcopes, Sky Opticks, Reading Glaſſes, from the ſmallest ſize to 12 Inches Diameter, Concaves, which burn by Reflection, from the least ſize to 20 Inches Diameter, Concave Cylinders and Cones of Metal. He has invented, a Pocket Microſcope, more uſeful than any yet made, opproved of by the Royal Society, and a large double Microſcope; Microſcopes according to Mr. Lewenhoek: Alſo Microſcopes of the ſaid Marſhals deſigning, a ſingular Invention for the advantage of Light, the like of which was never done before. Alſo a Tripple Perſpective, or Wheel Perſpective, having Three Concaves in one ſingle Eye Glaſs, accommodated to all ſights, Ages, Airs, and Places, never thought of by any other Man. He has alſo Speaking Trumpets, Cryſtal Priſms, and Spectacles fit for all Ages in Silver Tortoiſe-ſhell, Horn, or Leathern Frames by whole ſale or retail; with many other ſorts of Optick Inſtruments (for brevity ſake) not here named.
